taxonomicNotes: Has previously been confused with Leucoraja garmani (McEachran and Carvalho 2002).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Interspecific hybridization of the Pacific Sleeper Shark (S. pacificus) with the Greenland Shark (S. microcephalus) has likely been ongoing at the edges of their distributions since initial divergence (Walter et al. 2017).

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
The similar, but larger, Etmopterus bigelowi was previously confused with this species until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

Taxonomy remains unresolved for this species, with nominal records from various locations likely to represent other species (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is frequently misidentified with other regional etmopterids, e.g., Etmopterus burgessi (Schaaf-DaSilva and Ebert 2006). Therefore, care should be taken when identifying similar looking lucifer-group lanternsharks.

This species can be visually distinguished from two morphologically similar regional congeners, the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) and the Gulf of Mexico Smoothhound (M. sinusmexicanus) by several characters including fin shape and ampullary pore patterns (Giresi et al. 2013).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Rhynchobatus palpebratus is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

North Pacific Spiny Dogfish Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) has a rather long and convoluted taxonomic history. It was first described in 1854 as a separate species from the well-known Spiny Dogfish (Squalus acanthias) but was subsequently synonymyzed as the same species even though its life history parameters, meristics, morphometrics, and molecular data suggested otherwise. A comparative study of its morphometrics and meristics, as well as a molecular study on this species complex have revealed it to be distinctive from the North Atlantic and other S. acanthias forms elsewhere (Ebert et al. 2010).

The Dusky Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Galapagos Shark (Carcharhinus galapagensis). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
This is the revised taxonomic concept of Centrophorus grandulosus, which includes C. lusitanucs as a junior synonym; C. lesliei and C. longipinnis are also now split out as newly recognised species.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Some confusion exists regarding the publication date of the description of S. occulta (Faria et al. 2014). Some taxonomic literature sources list 1991 as the publication date while others list 1992. This confusion is probably due to the distribution of pre-prints of the article in 1991 before the full issue of the journal was printed in 1992. According to The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the publication date of the S. occulta description is 1991. There has also been discrepancy in referencing the species authority for S. occulta, particularly the name of the second author (Faria et al. 2014); K.G. da Silva’s surname has been spelled ‘da Silva’, ‘Da Silva’, and ‘Silva’. Faria et al. (2014) suggested using the one in the revisions by Vaz and Carvalho (2013) and in online taxonomic databases. Thus, the recommended citation is S. occulta Vooren & da Silva, 1991.

This species is comprised of two valid subspecies: Mustelus canis canis occurs on the continental shelf, whereas M. c. insularis occurs on insular shelves in the Caribbean (Heemstra 1997, Ebert et al. 2013).

The Potamotrygon leopoldi's dark dorsal background with white spots, that vary in shape and size, is similar mainly to that of Henle's Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon henlei) and Tapajós Freshwater Stingray (P. albimaculata) (Last et al. 2016, P. Charvet pers. obs. 2021). The juvenile dorsal colors of this species  resemble those of Henle's Freshwater Stingray, Tapajós Freshwater Stingray, and Ocellate Freshwater Stingray (P. motoro) and are sometimes mistaken for this species in the aquarium trade (Charvet-Almeida 2006).

Himantura signifer, H. kittipongi, and H. oxyrhynchus were placed within the newly described genus Fluvitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). This species is most similar to H. kittipongi, from which it differs in having no thorny denticles on the tail and a pale edge to the disc (Last et al. 2016b).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

The Galapagos Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Dusky Shark (Carcharhinus obscurus). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
Genetics studies have led some researchers to suspect that there may be an undescribed species of Echinorhinus off Oman and elsewhere in the Arabian Sea region (Henderson et al. 2016).

Squalus mitsukurii was once considered a globally distributed species, but recent morphological and genetic work suggests the species is restricted to temperate waters of Japan and Korea, and is possibly endemic to the Northwest Pacific (Pfleger et al. 2018, Ziadi-Künzli et al. 2020). The resolution of the species-complex is ongoing with further species likely being described in the future.
Himantura oxyrhynchus, H. signifer, and H. kittipongi and were placed within the newly described genus Fluvitrygon (Last et al. 2016a).
There is a single extant species in the family Mitsukurinidae.

Yano and Musick (1992) showed that morphometric characters used to separate Pacific Pseudotriakis acrales Jordan & Snyder, 1904 from Atlantic P. microdon de Brito Capello, 1868 did not differ significantly, and these authors confirmed P. acrales as a junior synonym of P. microdon. Pseudotriakis is thus a mono-specific genus.

Soares et al. (2016) redescribed Scyliorhinus haekelii, placing S. besnardi Springer & Sadowsky, 1970 as a synonym. Species of Scyliorhinus were further reviewed and redescribed by Soares and De Carvalho (2019), who recognised 16 valid species. Soares and De Carvalho (2019) also revised the geographic distribution of S. haeckelii, restricting its range to the southwestern Atlantic from southern Bahia, Brazil, to northern Argentina.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).
There are a number of errors in the original description (Hulley and Penrith 1966) which led Stehmann and Krefft (1988) to provide a detailed and accurate redescription.
The specific name has been misspelled and consistently used in the literature as Rhizoprionodon lalandei, but the original spelling R. lalandii should be retained.
Gymnura micrura has been redescribed with G. lessae and G. sereti split out from G. micrura as separate species (Yokota and Carvalho 2017).

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

This species has been mistaken mainly for Dasyatis (=Hypanus) say but also for Dasyatis pastinaca in the past. The specific name has been misspelled as hipostigma, including in the original description.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Until recently, the species name usually was spelled as sayi rather than say. This is not a synonymy, simply a change to conform to original spelling.

This Gulf of Mexico endemic species has sometimes been mistaken for the sympatric Dusky Smoothound (Mustelus canis) and Narrowfin Smoothhound (M. norrisi) in its limited offshore range (Heemstra 1997).
The western Atlantic and Pacific Ocean forms are thought to be different species (Ebert et al. 2013)
This species might be confused with the congener Cookiecutter Shark (Isistius brasiliensis).

Seigel et al. (1977) considered Squaliolus sarmenti and S. aliae as synonyms of S. laticaudus. Sasaki and Uyeno (1987) subsequently removed S. aliae from the synonymy as distinct and the genus now contains these two widely recognised species. Squaliolus laticaudus is sympatric with S. aliae in some regions.
The scientific name for this species is often misspelled as Carcharhinus perezii. Carcharhinus springeri Sadowsky & Amorim 1977 is considered a synonym (Soto 2001).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Nurse sharks occurring in the eastern Pacific were formerly considered part of this species concept, however the Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) has now been formally described as a separate species (Del Moral-Flores et al. 2015).
Previously confused with the similar but smaller Etmopterus pusillus until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).
This species is sometimes confused with Squalus clarkae and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).
Molecular studies are required to determine the level of genetic distinctness between the species in the Southwest Atlantic and the Southeast Pacific.

The spellings Dipturus trachyderma and Dipturus trachydermus have been used for this species. The basionym is Raja trachyderma and the valid name is Dipturus trachydermus following grammatical rules. While Fricke et al. (2019) use Dipturus trachyderma, we follow Last et al. (2016) which correctly uses Dipturus trachydermus.

Etmopterus baxteri Garrick, 1957 is a junior synonym of E. granulosus (Straube et al. 2015). Etmopterus tasmaniensis Myagkov & Pavlov, 1986 is a probable junior synonym of E. granulosus (Weigmann 2016).

Dipturus diehli Soto & Mincarone, 2001, as known only from the holotype taken off Santa Catarina, Brazil (29°39´S, 47°50´W) at a depth of 480 m, is likely a synonym of D. mennii and is treated here as such.

Based on geographical separation and differences in tooth row counts and coloration, Carvalho (1999) considered Narcine bancroftii and N. brasiliensis to be distinct species. However, intraspecific differences in tooth row counts among individuals of varying sizes were observed. Genetic analyses of Narcine specimens from throughout their range in the Western Atlantic Ocean are needed to confirm the presence of two species. Narcine bancrofti is a frequent misspelling of the species name.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, which is now recognised as a valid species (Last et al. 2016); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) centroura is now Bathytoshia centroura. This western Atlantic species is not conspecific with Bathytoshia of the eastern Atlantic (Last et al. 2016); the eastern Atlantic population that was formerly included within Dasyatis centroura is now included within B. lata (Last et al. 2016). The status of the single record from India is unknown.

Recent revisions have subdivided the previously wide-ranging Narcine brasiliensis into Narcine bancroftii (Griffith, 1834) which is widely distributed from North Carolina, USA, through parts of the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean Sea, the Greater Antilles, the Lesser Antilles and the northern coast of South America and Narcine brasiliensis (Olfers, 1831) which is endemic to the Southwest Atlantic in Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina (Carvalho 1999, Last et al. 2016).

This species is distinguished by the following characters: dorsal surface of the disc dark brown, with irregular yellow spots, oval to reniform, usually larger than eye diameter, teeth relatively, small, wider than long, with flat crowns. lack prominent cusps except in mature males. Middorsal tail spines low relatively to basal diameter, in irregular parallel rows (Rosa 1985).

The French Guiana Freshwater Stingray belongs to the “reticulated” color group being related to other species as Potamotrygon orbignyi and Potamotrygon histrix (Deynat, 2006). It is distinguished from other reticulated species by presenting vivid orange or brown smaller spots, teeth row, snout length, elongated and broad snout region (Silva and Carvalho, 2015). There is no taxonomic debate about its validity (Last et al.,2016).

Potamotrygon schroederi used to be a complex species with the recent described Potamotrygon tigrina (Carvalho et al., 2011). 
OLD
Taxonomic issues with this species are due in part to the fact that the holotype was originally in the private collection of Fernándo-Yépez and only the caudal sting, mouth and edge of the disc remain. Rosa (1985) when referring to Potamotrygon schroederi may have mistaken this species for a new species (presently in description by Ricardo Rosa and Maria Lúcia Araújo).

The Parnaíba Freshwater Stingray is a well established species with no doubts or debates about its validity (Last et al., 2016; Moro et al., 2016).

This species is often misidentified and may be mistaken with P. scobina, P. signata and P. falkneri (author's personal observations). Rosa (1985) indicated that these species together with P. castexi may form a species complex.

Before its original description, this species was recorded in the Lago de Maracaibo basin as Potamotrygon magdalenae (Schultz 1949, Fernández-Yépez and Espinoza 1970, Mago 1970). 
Originally described as Potamotrygon yepezi (Castex and Castello 1970). Since its description, it has not undergone generic relocations or nomenclature changes (Lasso et al. 1997, 2003,  Ortega-Lara et al. 2012, Lasso et al. 2013a, Lasso-Alcalá et al. 2013, Fricke et al. 2022). However, some authors have also designated it as P. magdalenae (Ewald et al. 1971, Andrade 1984, Galvis et al. 1997, Maldonado-Ocampo et al. 2005, see Distribution section).
Proposed name: Agustin Fernandez-Yepez stingray, Maracaibo basin stingray. Our opinion is that the name of Maracaibo river stingray should stop being used, since in addition to being somewhat confusing (Maracaibo is not just a river, but a basin), this species is not strictly of freshwater habits, as explained in the section of Habitat and Ecology.

This species shows a wide range of colour variation. Misidentifications occur with other potamotrygonid species such as P. constellata, P. castexi and possibly with P. motoro (Rincón pers. comm.) and P. humerosa.

Records from French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela this species are probably P. orbignyi (Carvalho et al. 2003). Live and fixed specimens are easily mistaken with P. orbignyi, P. humerosa and juveniles of P. brachyura (Charvet-Almeida and Almeida pers. obs.). P. histrix is also often misidentified as Potamotrygon sp. or Potamotrygon cf. histrix ("arraia cururu" from the Negro River basin) (Araújo pers. com.).

The lectotype designated by Castex (1969) is not considered valid (Rosa 1985, Carvalho et al. 2003).
This species has been confused with Raja montagui and Raja polystigma in the Mediterranean Sea (Bertozzi et al. 2003).

The antenna ray is a well-established species with only one congener, the dwarf antenna ray (Plesiotrygon nana). This species differs from it by different colour, spiracles, snout, nasal curtain, and numbers of teeth, vertebrae and tail length (Last et al. 2016).

Rough Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon constellata) was first described by Vaillant, 1880, and later Garman, 1913 described Potamotrygon circularis. Rosa (1985) considered in his review that P. circularis was a junior synonym of Potamotrygon constellata based on the presence of large tuberculae on the disc  margins. Later, other species also presented the large tubeculae on disc margins as well, and it is considered that further studies are necessary for taxonomic validity of this species (Lasso et al., 2013).  Last et al. (2016) considered this species to be a possible synonym of Reticulate Freshwater Stingray (Potamotrygon orbignyi) .

Marajó Freshwater Stingray was first described as a subspecies of Potamotrygon hystrix by Engelhardt (1912), and later reclassified by Rosa (1985) as a valid species. The type specimen described by Engelhardt was lost during the II World War, then Rosa (1985) based his reclassification on another specimen collected in the same area. So based on those data and that there was no record of the species after, Last et al. 2016 remarks this species as a possible synonym of Potamotrygon motoro.

There is some potential for confusion with regards the common names of this species. In some areas, Smalleyed Ray may be called Painted Ray or Sandy Ray, though these common names are also used for undulate ray Raja undulata and Leucoraja circularis respectively.

The Henle’s Freshwater Stingray taxonomic status has been recently reviewed Carvalho (2016) in comparison to P. rex and P. leopoldi and considered a valid species.
OLD TEXTSometimes misidentified with P. leopoldi or P. motoro. Needs correct identification and reliable diagnosis in order to control the ornamental fish trade in Amazonas, Pará and Tocantins States.

Potamotrygon schuemacheri is a species that is little represented in scientific collections (Rosa, 1985). It is a species that belongs to a group of stingrays with a pattern of reticulated dark pigment on the back (Carvalho et al. 2003). This fact is associated with missidentification, where P. schuemacheri is mistaken with other sympatric and syntopic species, such as P. histrix, P. falkneri, and even young individuals of P. brachyura. The ventral region of the species has dark margins, with some white spots.Potamotrygon schuemacheri has also been considered a junior synonym of P. histrix, but a taxonomic review is needed. Potamotrygon schuemacheri is sometimes referred to as P. schuhmacheri and P. schühmacheri. Although it was an improper latinization by deletion of the second "h" in “schuemacheri”, this spelling was adopted by Rosa (1985) based on the the first reviser principle, but referred to as P. schuhmacheri by Carvalho et al. (2003).

This species shows a wide range of color variation within juvenile and adult specimens (adults may present up to four completely different color patterns) (Almeida 2003). Misidentifications occur with several other freshwater stingray species, but especially with P. motoro (Rosa 1985), P. castexi and P. signata (Almeida 2003, author's pers. obs.).

There are no recent synonyms. In terms of identification, juvenile spotted rays can be confused with the morphologically similar blonde ray (Raja brachyura) and thornback ray (Raja clavata). Some spotted rays have fewer spots that are concentrated in the centres of the wings and can be misidentified as cuckoo rays (Leucoraja naevus).
Breviraja marklei McEachran & Miyake, 1987 is now recognised as a synonym of Rajella fyllae (Dyldin 2015, Weigmann 2016, Last 2016).
The species that has previously been referred to as Squatina dumeril in the southern Caribbean has recently been described as Squatina david by Acero et al. (2016).
Sometimes known as Cephaloscyllium sarawakense (Fricke et al. 2020).

Aetobatus ocellatus (Kuhl, 1823) was previously considered to be an Indo-West and Central Pacific form of the wider ranging Aetobatus narinari (Euphrasen, 1790). Comparative analysis of the morphology, molecular and parasite diversity has resulted in the redescription of A. ocellatus from tropical and warm-temperate waters of the Indian Ocean and West-Central Pacific Ocean with A. narinari being restricted to the Atlantic Ocean (Richards et al. 2009, White et al. 2010). Molecular analyses suggest greater levels of speciation within the Aetobatus genus, with distinguishable groups in the Western Indian Ocean and Northwest Pacific (Schluessel et al. 2010, White et al. 2010). Samples from Qatar cluster separately -- designated as A. cf. ocellatus 2 (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017). This requires further examination to delineate species boundaries.

Smith (1964) redescribed Cruriraja parcomaculata from the Eastern Cape of South Africa, assuming that the Cruriraja present in the Western and Eastern Cape was the same as von Bonde and Swart's R. parcomaculata from KwaZulu-Natal (Compagno and Ebert 2007). Smith also described C. triangularis from two specimens off Durban, as distinct from C. parcomaculata Smith, 1964. Re-examination of the type material by Compagno and Ebert (2007) and Aschliman et al. (2010) found that C. triangularis Smith, 1964 is in fact a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata (von Bonde and Swart, 1923), and concluded that the Cruriraja species common along the south and west coasts referred to as C. parcomaculata was an undescribed species. Aschliman et al. (2010) after a reviewing these species described a new species C. hulleyi while synonymizing C. triangularis as a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata. Therefore, information on the life history and distribution of C. triangularis prior to 2010 should now be referred to as C. parcomaculata, and life history and distribution information previously referred to for west coast C. parcomaculata is referable to as C. hulleyi. See Aschliman et al. (2010) for further explanation of this issue.

The taxonomy of Trygonorrhina spp. was previously confused because of problems with type information (Last and Stevens 2009, White and Last 2012). Two similarly patterned species were considered allopatric off southern Australia, i.e. the Southern Fiddler Ray (Trygonorrhina fasciata) off southern and southwestern Australia and the Eastern Fiddler Ray (T. sp. A) (Last and Stevens 1994) off eastern Australia. Based on the locality and the illustration of the T. fasciata type specimen, it was identified as the Eastern Fiddler Ray, thus replacing T. sp. A as the name for the eastern species. The Southern Fiddler Ray, previously called T. fasciata, was renamed as T. dumerilii Castelnau, 1873 based on the oldest available name which could be accurately attributed to the southern species (White and Last 2012). 

The Magpie Fiddler Ray (T. melaleuca) is now considered to be a colour variant of T. dumerilii (Donnellan et al. 2015).

Trygonorrhina fasciata differs from T. dumerilii by having a diamond-shaped marking behind the eyes, which are parallel in T. dumerilii.

A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
There is a possibility that this species is a complex, similar to the Dipturus batis-complex (Iglésias et al. 2010), but further taxonomic work is required.
Originally described in the genus Breviraja.

In some areas of the Mediterranean Sea (particularly along the Italian coasts) this species is probably misidentified with Raja montagui. Further investigation is required into this and morphometric and genetic studies are still in progress (Mancusi et al. 2005).
This species is most closely related to Hydrolagus affinis (Moura et al. 2005).

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species-groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). A. aphyodes belongs to the spongiceps-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length(TL)); 7 to 12 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows; a continuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Dipturus nidarosiensis may be a composite species with a small and large morphotype similar to that seen in Dipturus batis-complex (Iglesias et al. 2010) and Dipturus oxyrinchus-complex. Further genetic research is needed before a taxonomic revision is made, but Dipturus nidarosiensis refers to the larger morphotype and for now the smaller morphotype is referred to as Dipturus sp., as described in the Food and Agricultural Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) catalogue by Ebert and Stehmann (2013).
Formerly called Raja circularis. Early papers often confused Leucoraja circularis and Leucoraja naevus.

Raja maderensis, or a very similar species, is found in the Azores. The taxonomy and relationship of skates on these islands should be assessed. This species is now thought to be distinct from similar specimens from the Canary Islands and West Africa (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).

This species may have been confused with one other, and possibly two other species, causing uncertainty in some of the literature. Pristiurus jenseni Saemundsson, 1922, is considered a junior synonym of this species. Recent analyses indicate that life-history data collected from specimens of Galeus murinus are incompatible with Saemundsson’s (1922) description of Pristiurus jenseni and data on Galeus murinus, provided in Magnússon’s (2000) fishery survey. Consequently, two possibilities require investigation: (1) The synonym P. jenseni is a valid species from Iceland, larger than G. murinus, and commonly confused with it and/or (2) G. murinus is in part confused in Magnússon et al. (2000) with a larger species of Apristurus present in Iceland. Molecular phylogenetic analysis of G. murinus was conducted by Iglésias et al. (2005) and Pristiurus jenseni requires critical taxonomic examination.
This species was previously referred to as Raja naevus. Early papers often confused Cuckoo Ray with Sandy Ray (Lecoraja (Raja) circularis).
The subgenus Leucoraja was elevated to genus rank by McEachran and Dunn (1998).
Pristis pristis was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific. These are both now synonyms of P. pristis.

This species has been mistaken for P. yepezi from Lake Maracaibo (Rosa 1985). It is also pointed out as being easily mistaken for P. falkneri, P. signata and P. castexi in the ornamental trade (Ross and Schäfer 2000).
This species presents a great variation in coloration patterns, and it has been proposed that individuals from the upper part of the Magdalena basin (Embalse de Prado) differ from those from the lower part of the basin (Ortega-Lara, per. comm). Similarly, marketers argue that there are two morphs (red and black) in the Magdalena basin, but only the black ones (lower basin) are of ornamental interest. Genetic studies indicate that a population structure exists in five different localities of the lower (Mesolandia, Chimichagua and Ayapel) and middle (Paredes and Guarinocito) sub-basins of the Magdalena River, separated by three geographic barriers (Ramírez 2018).
OLDThis species has been mistaken for P. yepezi from Lake Maracaibo (Rosa 1985). It is also pointed out as being easily mistaken for P. falkneri, P. signata and P. castexi in the ornamental trade (Ross and Schäfer 2000).
Aetomylaeus caerulofasciatus has recently been described as distinct from the wider-ranging Indo-West Pacific A. nichofii (White et al. 2015).

This species is poorly represented in collections. The lack of specimens has caused some nomenclatural problems that have not been fully resolved. Older scientific names may apply to earlier growth stages of this species.

This species can be confused with other Amblyraja species with different distributions, such as Amblyraja georgiana (M. Stehmann pers. comm). In the northwest Atlantic, it is easily confused with Jensen' s skate (A. jenseni). Refer to Bigelow and Shroeder (1953), Jensen (1948) and Stehman and Burkel (1984).

Last and Stevens (2009) suggest that there are subtle shape differences between populations in the southwest of Western Australia compared to those in the northwest of Western Australia (the Pilbara region). They also suggest that habitat differences exist, with those in the north being found found well offshore, while those in the south are found near the shore. This warrants further investigation.
Originally placed under genus Halaelurus and subgenus Bythaelurus. Bythaelurus has now been elevated to generic level.

Carcharhinus dussumieri is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

Carcharhinus sealei is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

White, Ebert, and Compagno (2008) described the Western Gulper Shark (Centrophorus westraliensis) in 2008, as it previously had been considered to be synonymous with Centrophorous harrissoni McCulloch, 1915.

The Reticulate Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium hiscosellum) was considered by Last and Stevens (1994) to be conspecific with C. fasciatum Chan, 1966. White and Ebert (2008), however, described it as a distinct species, which is endemic to northwestern Australia.

The Flagtail Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium signourum) was described by Last et al. (2008) and was previously referred to in part as Cephaloscyllium sp. E in Last and Stevens (1994). In that volume, this species was thought to also occur off northwestern Australia, but that form has since been described as Cephaloscyllium speccum Last, Séret & White, 2008. As such, C. signourum is restricted to the Western Central Pacific and is known from certainty only off Queensland, Australia. Similar forms from New Caledonia, Vanuatu and Fiji need to be critically compared with the Australian specimens in order to determine their identity (Last et al. 2008).

The two undescribed species referred to in Last and Stevens (1994) as Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C are considered to be the same species by Last and White (2008) and Last and Stevens (2009), and were described as the Saddled Swellshark (Cephaloscyllium variegatum) by Last and White (2008). However, Last and Stevens (2009) note that the lumping of the tropical and temperate forms of the species (Cephaloscyllium sp. B and Cephaloscyllium sp. C, respectively) is provisional. Their relationship still requires some examination.

In the past, the Whitefin Chimaera (Chimaera argiloba) has been confused with the northern Pacific Silver Chimaera (Chimaera phantasma), however the Whitefin Chimaera differs in some morphological traits and lacks the dark stripes that characterise the Silver Chimaera (Last et al. 2008).

Confusion between this species and the Shortspine Chimaera (Chimaera obscura) has existed in the past, however the two species differ in some morphological traits; C. fulva is notably lighter in colour compared to C. obscura, and the two are genetically distinct (Didier et al. 2008).

Although only recently described (in 2002) this species has long been known to occur on deep-water slopes and fishing grounds around New Zealand and Tasmania (Paulin et al. 1989, Hardy 1990, Last and Stevens 1994).
The Southern African Frilled Shark C. africana Ebert & Compagno, 2009 is distinct from C. anguineus.

Previously this taxon was considered to be conspecific with Cirrhigaleus barbifer from the Northwest and Western Central Pacific. Further clarification of the taxonomic relationship between the two species is required.
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.
A taxonomic review of this group is required to properly identify the species of this genus.

The Pygmy Thornback Skate (Dentiraja flindersi) was first identified as Raja sp. M in Last and Stevens (1994) and is one of the smallest hard-nose skates. It appears to have been confused with other skate species and is a small relative of the Thornback Skate (D. lemprieri). The Pygmy Thornback Skate differs from the Thornback Skate by having an extremely broad interorbital space, nuchal thorns widely separated, and plain colour with fine white spots (Last and Stevens 2009). Some confusion remains with specimens collected from the inner continental shelf off Albany (southwestern Australia), which are most likely to be of a different species (Last and Stevens 2009).

Together with the closely related Pygmy Thornback Skate Dentiraja flindersi, D. lemprieri differs from other Australian skates in having a prominent blackish patch on the undersurface of the snout tip.
The Deepwater Skate (Dipturus acrobelus) was previously misidentified as Bight Skate Raja gudgeri (Last et al. 1983).
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus australis to the resurrected and elevated genus Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus cerva to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.
Last et al. (2016a) reassigned Dipturus endeavouri to the resurrected and elevated genera Dentiraja.

The False Argus Skate (Dipturus falloargus) is a short-nosed Dipturus species which differs from the Ocellate Skate (Dipturus oculus) in morphometrics and the lack of a well-developed ocellus on each pectoral fin, and differs from all other Dipturus spp. in body shape and colouration (Last 2008).
This species is often confused with other long-nosed skates.

The Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus) is a recently described species that is easily confused with other Australian members of the genus Dipturus, including the Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus apricus) and Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus) (Last and Stevens 2009).

Last (2008) considered the previously wider-ranging Dipturus polyommata (Ogilby, 1910) to consist of two species, the southern form was described as Dipturus endeavouri Last, 2008 and the northern form (that considered here) is the Argus Skate (D. polyommata). Last (2008) outlines in detail the justification for this taxonomic change and explains nomenclature.

Last and Yearsley (2002) discussed the generic placement of Australasian rajin skates. Six long-snout species were considered to conform closely with non-Australian members of the genus Dipturus. This group consists of the Bight Skate (Dipturus gudgeri), Heald's Skate (Dipturus healdi), Graham's Skate (Dipturus grahami), the Blacktip Skate (Dipturus melanospilus), Pale Tropical Skate (Dipturus acrobelus) and the Queensland Deepwater Skate (Dipturus queenslandicus). The Queensland Deepwater Skate is a problematic skate possibly involving two similar species. Unusual among Australian Dipturus skates in having the characteristic nuchal thorn either present or absent (usually present but it is easily removed). Individuals lacking a nuchal thorn can be confused with the Blacktip Skate. More specimens are required (Last and Stevens 2009).

Weng’s Skate (Dipturus wengi) appears to belong to a complex of closely related skate species that differ only slightly in their morphology (Last and Stevens 2009). Records of this species from off Indonesia and the Philippines are likely a different species.

The Sculpted Lanternshark Etmopterus sp. from Namibia and South Africa, has been referred to as E. cf. brachyurus, but is probably not conspecific with true E. brachyurus from the western Pacific (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is often confused with E. molleri and E. lucifer.
A poorly known species which is often misidentified. A similar species reported from the Western Indian Ocean may in fact represent a different species.
The taxonomy of Etmopterus unicolor remains unresolved (see Straube et al. 2011). Records from South Africa refer to E. compagnoi (Ebert et al. 2013).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Glaucostegus microphthalamus is currently considered a synonym of G. typus (W.T. White and D.A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).
Glyphis garricki is sympatric with G. glyphis in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea, but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).
Glyphis glyphis is sympatric with G. garricki in northern Australian and southern New Papua Guinea but the two are separable externally by colouration (Compagno et al. 2008).

The Australian Butterfly Ray has two distinct morphological variants which are principally separated by the presence or absence of a small dorsal fin (Jacobsen and Bennett 2009). Dorsal surface colouration can vary in this species from a uniform light green to a dark olive or grey-green and is highly dependent on the surrounding environment.
Previously this species was considered to be conspecific with H. boesemani but its taxonomy was recently resolved (White et al. 2007).

Hemigaleus australiensis is described as having substantially lower vertebral counts, much higher tooth counts in lower jaw, and a black-tipped second dorsal fin, separating it from Hemigaleus microstoma (White et al. 2005).

The taxonomic concept for Hexanchus nakamurai has been revised and Hexanchus vitulus has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Belize, Gulf of Mexico, and Bahamas) (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

Several species of sixgill stingrays have been named from the Western Pacific; H. longirostris, H. yangi, H. taiwanensis and H. brievirostra, mainly on snout length and shape. However, these forms may be based on variation with growth and state of preservation. The current opinion of the occurrence of a single species of sixgill stingray, H. bickelli based on morphological comparisons, should be confirmed by genetic analyses.

The Leopard Whipray (Himantura leoparda) is a recently described (2008) species closely related and similar in shape and dorsal disc pattern to the Reticulate Whipray (H. uarnak) and Honeycomb Whipray (H. undulata). These three species are in the ‘uarnak’ species-complex, a subgroup of mainly reticulated, ocellated or spotted whiprays. The Leopard Whipray can be distinguished by its unique arrangement of midscapular denticles and the leopard-like markings on the dorsal surface of adults and large specimens. Juveniles of the three species are born at different sizes and vary slightly in colour patterns and denticle shapes (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009). Taxonomic work is currently ongoing to more clearly define the sister species relationships (P. Last pers. comm. 2010).

Previously, this species has been misidentified as Dasyatis uarnak: Wallace 1967; Himantura fava: Compagno and Roberts 1982; Himantura sp. 1: Gloerfelt-Tarp and Kailola 1984; Himantura uarnak: Compagno 1986, Compagno et al. 1989; and Himantura undulata: Last and Stevens 1994, Last and Compagno 1999, White et al. 2006.

The Black Ghostshark (Hydrolagus homonycteris) is probably closely related to Abyssal Ghostshark (H. trolli), but the two differ in that the Black Ghostshark has a longer dorsal spine, smaller claspers and is darker in colour.

The Marbled Ghostshark differs from other species within the genus Hydrolagus through several morphological characteristics, by being lighter in colour and possessing a distinctive reticulated pattern (Didier 2008). Tissue samples for molecular sequencing have not been obtained to genetically distinguish the Marbled Ghostshark from other species (Didier 2008).
Insentiraja laxipella could be generically distinct. Unique among Australian skates, in lacking dorsal fins.

Shape differences are evident between populations across its range and need further investigation (Last and Compagno 1998). There is a need to ascertain if this species is conspecific with the population in the type locality (i.e., the Philippines).

The Western Spotted Gummy Shark (Mustelus stevensi) was recently described by White and Last (2008). It appeared in Last and Stevens (1994) as the undescribed Mustelus sp. nov. B, which was reported to occur both off western and eastern Australia. However, White and Last (2008) described the western form as M. stevensi, and the eastern form as M. walkeri.

The Eastern Spotted Gummy Shark (Mustelus walkeri) was recently described by White and Last (2008). It appeared in Last and Stevens (1994) as the undescribed Mustelus sp. nov. B, which was reported to occur both off western and eastern Australia. However, White and Last (2008) described the western form as M. stevensi, and the eastern form as M. walkeri.

Previously considered to be restricted to Australia. A recent taxonomic study by White et al. (2015) provided a redescription of the Purple Eagle Ray and the Japanese Eagle Ray (M. tobijei). The results of that study showed that previous records of the Japanese Eagle Ray from Indonesia, the Philippines, Taiwan and Okinawa in Japan actually refer to the Purple Eagle Ray. The Japanese Eagle Ray if confined to the western North Pacific, primarily in Japan. Thus, the Purple Eagle Ray's distribution is now extended from Australia north to Taiwan and southern Japan.

The Ornate Numbfish (Narcine ornata) is a recently described species of numbfish (Carvalho 2008). It has previously been confused with Banded Numbfish (Narcine westraliensis) that is found further south in Western Australia outside the range of this species (Last and Stevens 2009).

The Painted Maskray (Neotrygon leylandi) was formerly Dasyatis leylandi until resurrection of the genus Neotrygon by Last and White (2008). The Painted Maskray was previously considered to be more wide-ranging off northern Australia, before the eastern form was recently (2008) described as a new species, the Speckled Maskray (N. picta).

There is uncertainty about the identification of some specimens referred to as the Ningaloo Maskray (Neotrygon ningalooensis). Those from Shark Bay (Western Australia) and Gove (Northern Territory) need to be further validated as being the same species. There is some evidence that the Shark Bay population could represent an additional species (W.T. White unpubl. data 2010), which may affect the assessment of this species, as the restricted geographic range could become more of an issue with any threats.

The Speckled Maskray (Neotrygon picta) was thought to be a regional colour variant of Neotrygon (formerly Dasyatis) leylandi (Last, 1987) until described as a new species by Last and White (2008). The latter publication also resurrected the genus Neotrygon for the maskray species, Bluespotted Maskray (N. kuhlii), Painted Maskray (N. leylandi), Plain Maskray (N. annotata), Ningaloo Maskray (N. ningalooensis) and the Speckled Maskray.

The Blue Skate (Notoraja azurea) is a recently described species of Notoraja first recognized as distinct by Last and Stevens (1994). There is some regional variation in color pattern and meristics of this species that could result in separate species being described (Last and Stevens 2009).
Closely related to Notoraja subtilispinosa but distinct in many ways.
Four Notoraja species were previously identified by Last and Stevens (1994) but remained undescribed until recently (McEachran and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The Arafura Skate (Okamajei arafurensis) is a recently described species (Last and Gledhill 2008), not previously recognised. It is a new skate of the Indo–Pacific genus Okamejei. The species is morphologically similar to theYellow-spotted Skate (O. hollandi) from the western North Pacific and is also superficially similar to some Australian short-snout Dipturus species (Last and Gledhill 2008).

Orectolobus halei was previously synonymized with O. ornatus and was believed to be the adult form of O. ornatus. Taxonomic revision of New South Wales species showed that O. halei differs from O. ornatus in colour pattern (O. halei has black edges around saddles and is less freckled), an adult size larger than 120 cm total length, more dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (4–6), precaudal vertebrae count (>106), spiral valve count (>25), and two supraorbital knob. Morphometrically, O. halei has a shorter pelvic fin to anal fin interspace, larger pectoral fins, larger head dimensions, and relatively larger claspers in mature specimens (Huveneers 2006).

Orectolobus halei is also often confused with O. maculatus but differs with less dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (4-6) and a distinctive brownish upper body colouration with well-defined, darker brown saddles surrounded by black edges, and containing paler markings that lacks whitish rings and blotches (unlike O. maculatus) (Huveneers 2006).
As Orectolobus sp. nov. A, this was given a DISCARDED flag because is was an undescribed species assessed as LC; therefore it did not appear on the published Red List until 2009.

In New South Wales, O. maculatus is often confused with O. halei, but differs from O. halei by having more (6-10 dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group) and saddles containing whitish rings and blotches (unlike O. halei).

In Western Australia, O. maculatus was previously synonymised with O. parvimaculatus. Taxonomic revision of Western Australian species showed that O. maculatus differs from O. parvimaculatus by having have relatively smaller and less densely distributed ocelli and dorsal fins lacking dark markings (blackish marginal blotches present in O. parvimaculatus). The dorsal fins of O. maculatus are also smaller and less upright than those of O. parvimaculatus (Last and Chidlow 2008).
Records from Japan and the South China Sea are likely to be mis-identified O. japonicus or another undescribed species.

Orectolobus ornatus was previously synonimised with O. halei and was believed to be the juvenile form of O. halei. Taxonomic revision of New South Wales species showed that O. ornatus differs from O. halei in color pattern (more freckled in O. ornatus), an adult size smaller than 120 cm TL, fewer dermal lobes at the posterior preorbital group (3-4), precaudal vertebrae count (<106), spiral valve count (<25), and the absence of supraorbital knob. Morphometrically, O. ornatus has a longer pelvic fin to anal fin interspace, smaller pectoral fins, smaller head dimensions, and relatively smaller claspers in mature specimens (Huveneers 2006).

Assessment is complicated by taxonomic uncertainties based on the identification of the Papua New Guinea specimen. This species should at present be considered as an Australian endemic (L.J.V. Compagno, pers. comm.).

Orectolobus parvimaculatus has been confused in the literature with the larger O. maculatus (e.g., Compagno 1984, 2001, Last and Stevens 1994, Compagno et al. 2005, Hoese et al. 2006, Last and Chidlow 2008) and was believed to be juvenile O. maculatus. Taxonomic revision of Western Australian species showed that O. parvimaculatus differs from O. maculatus by having have relatively larger and more densely distributed ocelli, and dorsal fins with blackish marginal blotches (absent in O. maculatus). The dorsal fins of O. parvimaculatus are also taller and more upright than those of equivalent size O. maculatus (Last and Chidlow 2008).

The Network Wobbegong (Orectolobus reticulatus) was previously misidentified as the Northern Wobbegong (O. wardi) (Whitley 1939). Both species belong to a subgroup of small, morphologically similar wobbegongs, termed the ‘wardi-complex’. This species-complex contains at least three colour forms. All forms attain less than 100 cm total length and possess simple dermal lobes. Differences in colouration was initially thought to be intraspecific variation, however recent comparison of multiple specimens has shown that the forms differ consistently in colour, pattern and some morphological features. Further taxonomic and genetic research is required to elucidate the true number of species in the ‘wardi-complex’, their distributions and conservation status, but has not yet been possible due to the small number of specimens available for comparison. At this stage, the complex is considered to consist of the Northern Wobbegong, the Network Wobbegong and one (or more) potentially undescribed species (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The Northern Wobbegong (Orectolobus wardi) belongs to a subgroup of small, morphologically similar wobbegongs, termed the ‘wardi-complex’. This species complex contains at least three colour forms. All forms attain less than 100 cm total length and possess simple dermal lobes. Differences in colouration was initially thought to be intraspecific variation, however recent comparison of multiple specimens has shown that the forms differ consistently in colour, pattern and some morphological features. Further taxonomic and genetic research is required to elucidate the true number of species in the ‘wardi-complex’, their distributions and conservation status, but has not yet been possible due to the small number of specimens available for comparison. At this stage, the complex is considered to consist of the Northern Wobbegong, the Network Wobbegong (O. reticulatus) and one (or more) potentially undescribed species (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).

The genus Parascyllium was considered to comprise of four valid species. Last and Stevens (2008) described a fifth species – Elongate Carpetshark (Parascyllium elongatum) – characterised by a very short head, no dark collar in gill region and vertical rows of white spots on the body. It was described from a single specimen collected from the stomach of a School Shark (Galeorhinus galeus) in 1990.

This species is distinct in shape from all other stingarees, resulting in its placement in the separate monospecific family, Plesiobatidae. There has never been a comparison of populations of this species, which needs to be undertaken to elucidate whether there is in fact more than one species.

The Dwarf Sawfish (Pristis clavata) is similar to the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata), with which it may have been previously confused, but it has fewer rostral teeth than the Smalltooth Sawfish (Last and Stevens 2009).
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Scymnodon macracanthus (Regan 1906) (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.
There are two sympatric forms of this species which differ in colour pattern; the relationship between these forms requires study (Last and Stevens 2009).

Colour variation has been noted in this species with specimens from the northwest Pacific (Japan) noticeably darker in overall colour than those from the southwest Pacific (New Zealand) (Didier and Nakaya 1999). The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and solely based on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).
This ray is considered by some authors to be identical to the wide-ranging Javanese Cownose Ray (Rhinoptera javanica). Further systematic studies are required.
Molecular evidence supports the idea that Rhizoprionodon acutus is a complex of (at least) four species that needs further taxonomic investigation (Naylor et al. 2012).

Rhynchobatus australiae is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

The Western Legskate (Sinobatis bulbicauda) was recently described by Last and Séret (2008). In the species description Last and Séret (2008) elevated Sinobatis to the rank of genus on the basis of the conservative intragroup clasper morphology of its member species, and its strong differentiation from Hulley’s (1973) other subgenera Anacanthobatis.

The medium-sized Western Legskate has affinities to the slightly smaller species the Borneo Legskate (S. borneensis) (South and East China Seas). Based on its description of the adult male holotype, S. borneensis has a filamentous (vs. bulbous) tail and the snout is relatively longer with preorbital length 6.5 times the interorbital length (vs. 3.9–4.8 in adult males and 3.4–5.7 in all types of S. bulbicauda) (Last and Séret 2008). Additionally, adult males of the two species are not identical in size, S. borneensis, 31.7 cm total length (TL) (vs. 42.9–43.3 cm TL in S. bulbicauda) and also differ in many morphometric characteristics including their relative disc widths, precloacal lengths, preoral lengths, orbit diameters, mouth width, and intergill distances which will aid in differentiating the two species (see Last and Séret 2008 for measurement ranges).

The Blue Legskate (Sinobatis caerulea) was recently described by Last and Séret (2008) from five specimens. Last and Séret (2008) elevated Sinobatis to the rank of genus on the basis of the conservative intragroup clasper morphology of its member species, and its strong differentiation from Hulley’s (1973) other subgenera of Anacanthobatis. This species has been provisionally placed into the genus Sinobatis in the absence of an adult male specimen.  It may have been confused in the past with the smaller Western Legskate (S. bulbicauda).

Revision of Squalus in the Indo-Australasian region resulted in the resurrection of S. montalbani (Philippines, Indonesia, Australia) and S. griffini (New Zealand) and the description of S. chloroculus Last, White & Motomura, 2007. These species were previously considered to be conspecific with S. mitsukurii, which this work has revealed, does not occur in Australasian waters. Continued investigation of Squalus mitsukurii from around the world is resulting in more taxa being recognized.

Previously this species was included in Squalus sp. C. (= S. altipinnis) (Last and Stevens 1994). It was referred to as Squalus sp. C in Compagno et al. (2005) and as Squalus cf. sp. C in White et al. (2006).

The name Squalus megalops has been used widely for what represents a species-complex, with the true S. megalops endemic to Australia. Squalus acutipinnis has recently been resurrected as a distinct species (Viana and Carvalho 2016), and S. mahia and S. margaretsmithae have been described as new species (Viana et al. 2018).

Squalus montalbani was previously considered a likely junior synonym of S. mitsukurii but was resurrected as a valid species by Last et al. (2007). Referred to as Squalus sp. 1 in White et al. (2006a).
Formerly, U. asperrimus was the only species within Urogymmus. Last et al. (2016) added five more species to the genus.

The Banded Stingaree is morphologically similar to the Yellowback Stingaree (Urolophus sufflavus) and genetics are nearly identical; further investigation is required to confirm that these are separate species (Last et al. 2016).
Further investigation is required to confirm the species' Pacific distribution (Last et al. 2016).
Appears to hybridize with the Banded Stingaree (Urolophus cruciatis) at the southern end of its range. Further information is required to assess the validity of this species (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be a junior synonym of the Common Stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca), this species differs in disc shape, shape of the dorsal skin fold, and form and number of oral papillae (Last et al. 2016b).

The Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) and Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.

Carcharhinus coatesi is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

Carcharhinus tjutjot is part of the Carcharhinus seali-dussumieri group that has been revealed to consist of five species: C. dussumieri and C. sealei have recently been re-described, C. coatesi and C. tjutjot have been resurrected as valid species, and a new species, C. humani has been described (White 2012, White and Weigmann 2014).

White (2014) confirmed that Myliobatis australis Macleay, 1881 (from southern Australia) is a junior synonym of M. tenuicaudatus Hector, 1877 (which was previously considered to be endemic to New Zealand).

The Australian form of this species is provisionally identified as Apristurus melanoasper, although it is possible that the North Atlantic and southwestern Pacific forms represent distinct species (Last and Stevens 2009).
Forms provisionally assigned to Apristurus sinensis from Australian waters are genetically distinct and may represent separate species (Last and Stevens 2009).

Two very small juveniles were originally described by Bigelow and Schroeder as H. raleighana. However, it was recognised by Karrer in her 1972 description of H. haeckli, and by others, that some references to H. raleighana from the Canary Islands may actually be referred to H. haeckeli.

Nakayama et al. (2020) reviewed the genus Harriotta and merged H. haeckeli Karrer 1972 as a synonym of H. raleighana.

Synonyms = Hydrolagus sp. C Paulin et al., 1989; Hydrolagus sp. cf lemurs Séret in Grandperrin et al., 1997; Hydrolagus sp. Séret in Grandperrin et al., 1999.

A recently described, highly distinctive species, Hydrolagus trolli is often caught with a species of giant black chimaera (cf. Hydrolagus affinis), and the range of these two species may overlap in some areas, but H. trolli is readily separated by its distinctive blue colouration and more acute snout.
The literature suggests that this species may also occur off the coasts of Ecuador and Peru, but these records are unconfirmed and may have been misidentifications of another species.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 32 described species and a relatively large number of potentially undescribed ones. Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). The brunneus-group is characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length <6% total length (TL), 0.36 to 0.94 times in interorbital); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Compagno (1984) considered it likely that the specimens and records of A. brunneus from the western North Pacific represent an assemblage of two or more brunneus-like species.

A. spongiceps is readily distinguished from its congeners by its unique pleated gills (Compagno 1984).

Shark species within the genus Mustelus are very similar in both appearance and size, making proper identifications challenging. Five species of Mustelus are known to frequent the waters surrounding Baja California. One of these five species, M. albipinnis, was only recently described and has likely been misidentified in the past as other Mustelus spp. (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005). Mustelus albipinnis is distinguished from M. californicus by white margins present on its fins and a habitat preference for deeper waters (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Another Baja California smooth-hound, M. lunulatus is considered to be the most similar to M. californicus due to similar colour patterns (grey dorsal colouration with a lighter ventral side). Mustelus lunulatus can be distinguished from M. californicus by its wider set eyes, longer snout and shorter upper labial furrows (Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Both species, however, have well developed lower caudals and molariform teeth (Ebert et al. 2013). Dentition can be used to distinguish M. californicus from both M. dorsalis and M. henlei which both have sharper high-cusped teeth (Starks 1917, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005, Ebert et al. 2013). Mustelus henlei can also be differentiated by the dorsal fins, which are frayed at the posterior margins and more anteriorly placed along the body than M. californicus (Starks 1917, Ebert 2003, Ebert et al. 2013).

The Brown Smooth-hound was originally described as Rhinotriacis henlei by Gill in 1863. This name was changed to Triakis henlei and then to the currently valid name Mustelus henlei (Gill 1863).

In the past, misidentification has lead to a lack of information about the basic biology of the Mustelus species in the Gulf of California. A recent taxonomic revision of this group in the Northern Gulf of California and off southwest peninsula of Baja California has identified a fourth smooth-hound species (Castro-Aguirre et al. 2005, Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005).

This species may have been misidentified for other Mustelus spp. in the Gulf of California, including M. californicus. Records of this species from South America refer to another undescribed lunulatus-type Mustelus species. This lunulatus-type Mustelus occurs in the Eastern Pacific to Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands and has likely been recorded as M. lunulatus in South America in the past (see Compagno in prep. for discussion).
There are possible taxonomic problems in tropical latitudes (possible confusion with Zapteryx xyster), which may severely limit the functional range of  Z. exasperata (Ebert 2003).

Bathyraja kincaidii is very similiar morphologically to Bathyraja interrupta and these have been considered to be the same species by some authors. However, Knuckey (2017) clarified that these species are distinct.

This species was first described from the Bering Sea (57°47'N, 173°47'W) by Ishiyama and Ishihara (1977). Subsequent Russian authors have considered this species a junior synonym of Bathyraja matsubarai (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999, Mecklenburg et al. 2002). However, recent Russian literature (e.g. Grigorov and Orlov 2013), and other authors, have considered B. lindbergi to be a valid species (Compagno 1999, Compagno 2005). Information from Alaska appears to pertain only to B. lindbergi. Bathyraja lindbergi and B. matsubarai are very similar and further taxonomic study is required on both species.

This skate been misidentified as the Roughtail Skate, Bathyraja trachura, but B. microtrachys is clearly a distinct species. Although adult males have not been observed for this species, egg cases have been collected and are distinct from those of other eastern North Pacific skates (D.A. Ebert unpubl. data).

In the Northeast Pacific this species has been misidentified on occasion with the starry skate, Raja stellulata, but these skates are distinctive from each other. Bathyraja parmifera is somewhat common in the Gulf of Alaska, but does not appear to occur south of this area, while R. stellulata does not appear to occur as far north as the Gulf of Alaska. B. parmifera and B. smirnovi have also been considered similar (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999, Parin 2001) though this seems questionable (Sheiko and Fedorov 2000, H. Ishihara pers. obs.).

B. simoterus is a synonym of B. parmifera (H. Ishihara pers. comm. 2007).
Some authors (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999) suggest B. trachouros and B. violacea may be synonymous.
This skate is often misidentified with other hardnose skates from the northeast and eastern central Pacific.

First described by Jordan and Gilbert (1880). Gilbert (1915) described Raja montereyensis based on an adult male of this species. However, R. montereyensis was later determined to be a junior synonym of R. stellulata.

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The nomenclature of this species is often confused, occasionally resulting in the listing of brevis and dipterurus as separate species. Both Jordan and Gilbert and Garman published descriptions of this species in the same year, 1880. However, Jordan and Gilbert published their account of specimens from San Diego in May 1880, while Garman published his description in October of that year. Garman (1913) subsequently overlooked these facts and inappropriately synonymized dipterurus with brevis. However, Jordan and Gilbert's description has precedence.
Myliobatis californica Gill, 1865 was a misspelling of this species.
Fowler (1910) stated that Chimaera neglecta Ogilby, 1888 is probably a synonym of H. colliei, but it is more likely to be a synonym of H. novaezealandiae (Didier and Rosenberger 2002).

Bathyraja interrupta was first described by Gill and Townsend (1897) from a type specimen from the Bering Sea. It was initially placed into the genus Raia, which has undergone several revisions since. Dolganov (1983) and Compagno (1999) reallocated this species to the genus Rhinoraja. Eschmeyer (2016) considers the genus Rhinoraja valid, but lists this species within Bathyraja. Both scientific names are still in use.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).
Aetomylaeus caerulofasciatus has recently been described as distinct from the wider-ranging Indo-West Pacific A. nichofii (White et al. 2015).
The assessment has been amended in September 2016 to reflect newly available information which places this species in the genus Raja (formally Malacoraja).

The species was first described by Risso (1810) as Squalus ferox from the type locality at Nice and most early records were from the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic. Whitley (1950) described O. herbsti from southeastern Australia, differentiating it from O. ferox mainly on differences in dental formulae, and the absence of pigment spots. Garrick's (1974) account of two specimens from New Zealand cast doubt on any differences in dentition between the species but retained O. herbsti for the plain-coloured Odontaspis.

However, Compagno (1984) reviewed the two species and considered that O. herbsti was a junior synonym of O. ferox, noting (as did Robins et al. 1980) that the presence or absence of spots was highly variable, much as with Carcharias taurus. The existence of spotted specimens outside the Mediterranean Sea, including from California (Seigel and Compagno 1986), is supported by in-situ observations made off Lebanon, New Zealand and Malpelo Island (Columbia), where specimens exhibit considerable variability in the presence, density and size of spots. There may be some regionalised trends controlling the intensity of such pigmentation. In the absence of any further evidence to support the validity of an O. ferox/O. herbsti dichotomy, recognition of the single Odontaspis ferox of Risso, as previously argued by Compagno (1984, 2001), remains valid.

Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. The taxonomic validity of this species is in question and requires review. However, until such time as this problem is solved it is treated as a valid species.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

This species was previously confused with other guitarfishes and erroneously considered to be widespread in the Indo-Pacific. Rhinobatos formosensis from Taiwan is now known to be a junior synonym of R. schlegelii (Last et al. 2016a, Last et al. 2016b).
The species is distinguished from its regional congeners, the Bottlennose Guitarfish (Rhinobatos schlegelii) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (Last et al. 2014).

The taxonomy of the 'whitespotted wedgefish' species-complex (which includes several Indo-West Pacific wedgefishes) is not fully resolved, and the status of the Taiwanese Wedgefish is in need of critical re-evaluation by comparing it to other regional species.
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus flagellum, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White et al. 2013).

Recent changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos have elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Séret and McEachran (1986) tentatively synonymised Glaucostegus petiti (reported from the Western Indian Ocean) with G. cemiculus because the morphometrics and the meristics of the holotype and only known specimen of G. petiti fell into the ranges of variation of G. cemiculus. Glaucostegus cemiculus is an Eastern Atlantic species, however, and does not occur in the Western Indian Ocean from which G. petiti is reported (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008). It is possible that there was a mistake in the origin of the type specimen, although the collector Georges Petit did explore the Tuléar region of Madagasar. No further specimens of Glaucostegus petiti have been found to date, despite the presence of an active research station in Tuléar for decades, although other guitarfishes (Acroteriobatus annulatus and Rhinobatos holcorhynchus) have been collected from the region (Bernard Séret pers. comm. 2008).

Glaucostegus petiti is considered a synonym of G. cemiculus (William T. White and David A. Ebert pers. comm. 2016).

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, but it is now recognised as a valid genus (Last et al. 2016a); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) lata is now Bathytoshia lata. Molecular data (G. Naylor pers. comm. 1 November 2012) provide evidence that Bathytoshia (as Dasyatis) lata, D. thetidis Ogilby, 1899, D. ushiei (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925), and eastern Atlantic stingrays identified as D. centroura (e.g. McEachran and Capapé 1984), are populations of D. lata (Last et al. 2016a). The species was originally described by Garman (1880) from Hawaii and also confirmed by Fowler (1941). Teng (1962) reported this species from Taiwan (1962) although the record from Taiwan may be a different species.

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the morphologically conservative genus Telatrygon and moving zugei across to this new genus. Telatrygon crozieri (Blyth, 1860) from the northern Indian Ocean is considered distinct from T. zugei (which occurs in the western Pacific).
Last et al. (2016a) resurrected the species Telatrygon crozieri (Blythe, 1886) from its former synonymy with Dasyatis (=Telatrygon) zugei.

Further investigations are needed to determine the position of this species in the order Myliobatiformes, but it may belong in its own family (Last et al. 2016).

Previously included within Neotrygon kuhlii, N. australiae was described as a separate species by Last et al. (2016a). The Neotrygon genus has recently been split and currently includes at least 11 species. It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. More work is required to fully understand where each member of the Neotrygon genus occurs.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).

This species is often mistaken with Hypanus guttatus but snout length and pelvic fin shape differ.
