Himantura heterurus has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon heterura is the correct name of a common western Pacific species, misidentified as Himantura (=Brevitrygon) walga; B. walga is confined to the Indian Ocean (Last et al. 2016a).
Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within their newly described genus Brevitrygon.

The genus Himantura has been further revised by Last et al. (2016). Himantura, which was once represented widely in the Indo–West Pacific by ~20 species, is now restricted to a group of four large Indo–Pacific species with strong colour patterns (Last et al. 2016). Himantura astra is now within the newly erected genus Maculabatis, along with eight other medium to large marine whiprays that were previously placed in Himantura (Last et al. 2016).

Himantura (=Maculabatis) astra had previously been confused with Himantura (=Maculabatis) toshi and the two forms had been considered to be a single species, however they are now known to be two morphologically distinct species. Himantura toshi (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) was renamed H. astra Last, Manjaji-Matsumoto & Pogonoski, 2008 (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009) and Himantura sp. A (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) is considered to be H. toshi Whitley, 1939 (Last et al. 2008, Last and Stevens 2009).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including macrura).

The genus Himantura has been further revised by Last et al. (2016). Himantura, which was once represented widely in the Indo–West Pacific by ~20 species, is now restricted to a group of four large Indo–Pacific species with strong colour patterns (Last et al. 2016). Himantura toshi is now within the newly erected genus Maculabatis, along with eight other medium to large marine whiprays that were previously placed in Himantura (Last et al. 2016).

The Brown Whipray (Himantura (=Maculabatis) toshi) had previously been confused with the Blackspotted Whipray (Himantura (=Maculabatis) astra) and the two forms had been considered to be a single species; however they are now known to be two morphologically distinct species. Himantura sp. A (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) has been named H. toshi (Last and Stevens 2009), and Himantura toshi (sensu Last & Stevens, 1994) was renamed H. astra (Last and Stevens 2009).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including fai).

This species is frequently misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) jenkinsii.

Formerly monotypic (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more large to very large species to Urogymmus, including dalyensis.

The Freshwater Whipray (Urogymmus dalyensis) is a recently described species which was previously referred to as Himantura chaophraya Monkolprasit & Roberts, 1991 (for example, in Last and Stevens 1994). Himantura chaophraya was considered to occur in Southeast Asia and in northern Australia. However, Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto (2008) consider the Australian form to be distinct from the Southeast Asian form, and they described the former as Himantura (=Urogymmus) dalyensis. They also clarified the correct name for the Southeast Asian species as Himantura (=Urogymmus) polylepis (Bleeker, 1852). Thus, the name H. chaophraya is invalid.
This species requires further taxonomic research and it is possible that populations in the Mekong and other drainage systems may pertain to other species (Vidthayanon et al. 2016).
This species was previously confused with Pastinachus sephen with which it co-occurs (Last and Manjaji-Matsumoto 2010).
The taxonomic status and validity of this species is uncertain. The only known specimen (which may be lost) may have actually been an Apristurus species.

A record of an egg capsule from the Indian Ocean identified as Harriotta indica (Balakrishnan 1962), as well as records of H. pinnata in the Arabian Sea and Southwest India (Manilo and Movchan 1989, Silas and Selvaraj 1980) probably refer to this species.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

This species was first described by Gubanov and Schleib (1980) but Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) described it as a separate species, Chiloscyllium confusum, without mention of C. arabicum. Compagno (1984) provisionally recognized C. arabicum but noted it was apparently very close to C. punctatum. Dingerkus and DeFino's account clearly establishes this species as separate from C. punctatum (Compagno 2001).

This species has been widely misreported as C. griseum, at least in the Arabian Gulf, and the distribution of these two similar species requires clarification. There is a high need for taxonomic investigation regarding species in the genus Chiloscyllium in the Arabian Sea region (D. Ebert pers. comm. 2017).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Acroteriobatus variegatus is morphologically very similar to A. zanzibarensis, with only subtle differences in mitochondrial DNA between the two species. Further work is required to clarify their relationship (Last et al. 2016b).

This species was confused with H. buergeri until Springer and D'Aubrey (1972) found it to be a different species (Compagno 1984). Previously considered to occur in the Philippines, Viet Nam and northwestern Australia but two new species recently described from Indonesia/Philippines and northwestern Australia have resulted in a more restricted range for this species (White et al. 2007). The Viet Nam populations need to be examined further as it is unsure which Halaelurus species they are (W. White pers. obs).

Previously Torpedo suessi was considered a junior synonym of T. sinuspersici (Carvalho et al. 2002). Garman (1913) considered T. suessi to be a valid species, but thought that it may be synonymous with T. panthera. However, Carvalho et al. (2002) believe that this is not possible due to the inconceivability that the ornate colour pattern of T. suessi could transform into the typical pattern of small, irregular whitish spots present in T. panthera. Rather than being a synonym of T. sinuspersici, or T. panthera, it is much more likely that T. suessi is a valid species that occurs at least in the southern Red Sea (Carvalho et al. 2002). This species may also be identifiable with the paralectotype of T. fuscomaculata, but there is some uncertainty surrounding this, and T. suessi would still prove to be a valid species even it if it was conspecific with the paralectotype (Carvalho et al. 2002).
Although only recently described (Carvalho et al. 2002), the Bigeye Electric Ray (Narcine oculifera) is distinctive and is not easily confused with any other electric rays.

The female holotype of the Pita Skate was comprehensively examined in a recent taxonomic assessment of Okamajei (Weigmann et al. 2015). This showed unequivocally that the Pita Skate does not belong to the genus Okamejei, but instead to either Leucoraja or Rajella. This is evidenced by its overall appearance, particularly the absence of dark-marked ventral pores (vs. dark marked ventral pores present in Okamejei), a rather short and thick tail (vs. a long and slender tail), a very short interdorsal space (vs. a wide interdorsal space), and a short postdorsal tail section (vs. a long postdorsal tail section). Due to the lack of an adult male specimen and the accordingly unknown clasper characters, the Pita Skate specimen cannot definitely be assigned to a genus and for the time being should be placed as incertae sedis in the general genus Raja Linnaeus. More specimens are urgently needed (Weigmann et al. 2015).

Himantura imbricata has been placed within the newly described genus Brevitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). Brevitrygon imbricata is very similar to B. walga (it is often confused with B. walga), particularly in general disc shape, however their geographical distributions appear limited and almost non-overlapping (P. Last pers. obs). The former is apparently found only in the Indian Ocean, the latter in the South China Sea. Two forms of B. imbricata are recognized, based on the morphology of the tail.
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis to consist of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including randalli).
Aetomylaeus milvus is considered to be distinct from A. maculatus (Last et al. 2016).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Himantura heterurus, H. imbricata, H. javaensis, and H. walga within the new genus Brevitrygon, previously confused with other dwarf whiprays (Brevitrygon species) (Last et al. 2016b). There remains considerable taxonomic confusion over 'B. walga' with different forms across its range. These may turn out to represent a series of different species.
This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016a).

The Lost Shark is a recently described, distinct, whaler shark of the Carcharhinus porosus subgroup (White et al. 2019a). Originally described as Carcharhinus obsolerus, the correct spelling is actually Carcharhinus obsoletus (Dubois and Seret 2019, White et al. 2019b).

The Java Stingaree is known only from the type specimen and is considered valid with the holotype housed at the Humboldt-Universität, Museum für Naturkunde, Zoologisches Museum, Berlin, Germany. It is a unique species of stingaree and its placement in the genus Urolophus is provisional (Last et al. 2016). It is the only known stingaree (family Urolophidae) from Java; the Kai Stingaree (Urolophus kaianus), the only other stingaree known from Indonesia, doesn't overlap with the historical range of the Java Stingaree (Last et al. 2016).

The genus Apristurus is one of the most taxonomically confused groups of sharks. Most species are superficially very similar and many have been poorly described. Sexual dimorphism in some species, and changes in body proportions with growth also complicate identification. There are at least seven species of Apristurus in New Zealand, however taxonomy and identification issues remain unresolved (Ford et al. 2015, Roberts et al. 2015).
Last, Burgess and Séret (2002) suggest that Etmopterus caudastigmus, E. splendidus and E. fusus might be placed within a different genus.

This species has been reported from New Caledonia in an unpublished checklist of fishes. However, the specimens from there represent an undescribed species of Gollum (Gollum sp. B in Ebert et al. 2013).

Viana and de Carvalho (2018) propose S. rancureli as a junior synonym of S. melanurus, however the reported differences in colour pattern, morphology and mersitics indicate that further sampling, and a genetic comparison of the two nominal species is needed to support their synonymy. The distributions of Squalus melanurus and S. rancureli also need to be clarified through examination of collected materials. The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.
Typhlonarke tarakea Phillipps, 1929 is probably based on a poorly preserved specimen of T. aysoni (Last et al. 2016), and the genus Typhlonarke is here treated as monospecific.

The species was described in 1971 from nine specimens collected from southern New Zealand. However, the collection locality of the holotype and four paratypes was incorrectly reported as 44°32.5' S, 166°41' E which is in depths of several thousand metres; it should be 46°32.5' S, 166°41' E.
he taxonomy for this species was recently resolved and described. Specifically it is distinct from congeners in the Coral Sea.
The Kermadec Spiny Dogfish (Squalus raoulensis) is superficially very similar to the Northern Spiny Dogfish (S. griffini) but is a member of the S. megalops–cubensis species complex.

Somniosus longus from the Pacific Ocean has long been considered a synonym of S. rostratus from the Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea (Compagno 1984, Francis et al. 1988, Compagno 1999). Yano et al. (2004) resurrected S. longus on the basis of several morphological and meristic characters. However their sample sizes of S. longus and S. rostratus were too small to properly define the range of variation in these characters, so their conclusion needs verification using larger sample sizes and preferably DNA analyses. Nevertheless, S. longus has been considered valid by recent authors (Ebert et al. 2013).

Brochiraja aenigma remains poorly defined. A recent trawl survey to the type locality provided no additional specimens. Hence, its generic placement is provisional because features of adult males are unknown, and the only known female lacks a rostral thorn and is in a poor state of preservation. Within the southwest Pacific it is unique in appearance having a rounded disc covered in very fine granular denticles, a very long tail, and high meristic values (Last and McEachran 2006).

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: The Broken Ridge Skate (Notoraja lira) is a recently described species (McEachran and Last 2008).

The Sapphire Skate (Notoraja sapphira) was first documented in 1996, when a single specimen was collected on the Norfolk Ridge, and thought to be a member of the genus Pavoraja (Séret in Grandperrin et al. 1997). In 2006, four more specimens were collected, and it was determined that the specimens were all part of the genus Notoraja (Last and Séret in Anonymous 2006). The Sapphire Skate was described from these five specimens, and comparison with its closest congener, Blue Skate (N. azurea), found the two species to be distinct.

The Northern Spiny Dogfish (Squalus griffini) is a member of the S. mitsukurii species complex (‘mitsukurii-group’).

Garrick (1960) reviewed the Australasian species of Squalus and incorrectly synonymised S. griffini and S. fernandinus Molina, 1782 (sensu Bigelow and Schroeder 1948, 1957) with S. blainvillii (incorrect spelling of S. blainville (Risso, 1827), Eschmeyer 1998). Garrick recognised S. acanthias and S. blainville from New Zealand, and S. acanthias, S. blainville and S. megalops from Australia. Squalus blainville was thought to be widespread in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans (Bigelow and Schroeder 1948, 1957; Garrick 1960). Chen et al. (1979) subsequently defined S. blainville from Japan as a species with high dorsal fins and long dorsal-fin spines. They observed that Squalus, referred to S. fernandinus and S. blainville by Bigelow and Schroeder (1948) and Garrick (1960) had short dorsal-fin spines and were more similar to S. mitsukurii from Japan, and suggested that nominal S. blainville from New Zealand could be identical to S. mitsukurii. Compagno (1984) also noted that dogfishes resembling S. mitsukurii occurred off Australia and New Zealand, and did not recognise S. blainville from the Southern Hemisphere. As a consequence this species was widely synonymised with S. mitsukurii (Paulin et al. 1989, Yano in Amaoka et al. 1990, Roberts 1991, Paul and Heath 1997, Cox and Francis 1997, Anderson et al. 1998, Compagno et al. 2005). Last and Stevens (1994) provisionally mapped New Zealand populations as S. mitsukurii but suggested that regional forms may represent a species complex. This species was formally resurrected and re-described by Duffy and Last (2007).

Genetic evidence indicates that a morphologically inseparable taxon occurring on Gascoyne Seamount, Tasman Seamount Chain, is a distinct species (Ward et al. 2007). Sequencing of the barcode region of mtDNA CO1 by Ward et al. (2007) groups this taxon with Squalus chloroculus but it is morphologically distinct from that species. The only specimen of this taxon is NMNZ P.38327.
Squatina aculeata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fisher reports are often assigned only to the genus level. Misidentification is common.
Squatina oculata is difficult to identify to the species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports are often assigned only to genus level.

The Chilean Angelshark (Squatina armata), has previously been considered to be conspecific with the Pacific Angelshark (S. californica). Recent molecular evidence places S. armata as the sister taxon to the Neotropical angel sharks, indicating it is a distinct species (Stelbrink et al. 2010). Given its prior taxonomic placement, some literature on the elasmobranch fauna of Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia list S. californica as part of their coastal fauna, while others only mention S. armata. To add to the confusion, some country checklists include both S. armata and S. californica (see Cornejo et al. 2015). These records of S. californica occurring sympatrically with S. armata are likely incorrect, thus for the purpose of this assessment all angel shark records in the Southeast Pacific are considered to be S. armata. Further research is needed to elucidate the distributions of S. armata and S. californica, particularly in the Pacific coast of Central America and the northwest coast of South America.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).
The taxonomy and nomenclature of the Neotrygon kuhlii species-complex has been problematic. It has largely been resolved with the description of several new species (Last et al. 2016).
This species formerly included Teanira lessoni, which is now recognised as a separate species (Last et al. 2016).
Taeniura lessoni Last, White & Naylor, 2016 has recently been described as distinct from the wide-ranging T. lymma (Forsskål, 1775).

This species has strong molecular divergence from the once conspecific Coach Whipray (Himantura uarnak) and from another reticulate whipray, Honeycomb Whipray (Himantura undulata) (Last et al. 2016a). It can be morphologically distinguished from the Coach Whipray by a more pronounced reticulate pattern in adults, with work to elucidate smaller individuals still in progress, and it can be distinguished from the Honeycomb Whipray by smaller reticulations and a lack of suprascapular denticles (Last et al. 2016a).
This species belongs to the small, recently designated Telagtrygon genus that consists of four species in the tropical Indo-Pacific (Last et al. 2016a).
Scymnodon plunketi may be a junior synonym of Centroscymnus macracanthus (White et al. 2015). Taxonomic clarification is required.

Torpedo fairchildi and Torpedo macneilli were recently synonymized with the Great Torpedo Ray (Torpedo nobiliana) and the Western Atlantic Torpedo Ray (Tetronarce occidentalis) is now recognized as a valid species based on molecular data (Carvalho et al. 2016).
Previously included within Tetronarce nobiliana, T. occidentalis is now recognised as a separate species (Carvalho et al. 2016).

Until this species' formal description in 2016 (Acero et al. 2016), angel sharks caught in the southern Caribbean were thought to be Squatina dumeril. Further work is needed to determine whether and where the ranges of these two species overlap.

Viana and de Carvalho (2018) propose S. rancureli as a junior synonym of S. melanurus, however the reported differences in colour pattern, morphology and mersitics indicate that further sampling, and a genetic comparison of the two nominal species is needed to support their synonymy. The distributions of Squalus melanurus and S. rancureli also need to be clarified through examination of collected materials. The correct taxonomic authority for this species requires clarification.

Angel sharks (Squatina spp.) in the Eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean are difficult to identify to species level, therefore many of the records from fishermen reports in the Mediterranean are often assigned only to genus level. Squatina squatina is the only species to occur in the Northeast Atlantic from Portugal northwards.

Rhynchobatus djiddensis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.
Previous taxonomic issues relating to Paratrygon aiereba have been resolved by Rosa (1985).

Glyphis gangeticus was originally described from the Hooghly River, India. Records of G. gangeticus are sparse and there have been previous issues with reporting due to misidentification with other carcharhinds, mainly the Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) and Broadfin sharks (Lamiopsis spp.), resulting in historic ambiguities about the range of G. gangeticus. The taxonomic status of the species was recently resolved with Li et al. (2015) demonstrating that G. siamensis and G. fowlerae are synonyms of G. gangeticus. Based on molecular data, there is an undescribed Glyphis species currently known from Bangladesh and Malaysian Borneo (Li et al. 2015).
Haploblepharus edwardsii is commonly misidentified for other Haploblepharus species.

Mustelus mustelus and M. asterias are morphologically similar and may be misidentified. Many early works may refer to either of the two species (Wheeler 1978). Mustelus asterias is distinguished from M. mustleus by a narrower inter-narial space and the presence of white spots on the dorsal and upper lateral sides of the former.

There is a demonstrated high level of contemporary and historical misidentification of unspotted Mustelus asterias as M. mustelus in the Northeast Atlantic Ocean region (Farrell et al. 2009, Farrell 2010). There are no reliably confirmed records of M. mustelus occurring north of Portuguese waters (Farrell 2010). Quignard and Capapé (1972) described a M. mustelus specimen from Portuguese Atlantic Ocean waters based on dermal denticle morphology and this remains the most northerly reliably identified record of this species. Similarly, some misidentification can occur between M. mustelus and M. punctulatus. This is because the black spots on the body are not unique to M. punctulatus and their absence is not diagnostic for M. mustelus. The distance of the nostrils and the shape of the mouth appear to be more useful features to distinguish the two species during fieldwork (Marino et al. 2018).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Taxonomy of the genus Centrophorus has been much controverted during the last fifty years. Part of the confusion has been focused on two species with sessile dermic denticles (thus different from C. squamosus) whose most conspicuous anatomic differences are maximum size and size at sexual maturity. The species assessed here is to be considered the “smaller” species, and has been recently reported under the name of C. granulosus or C. uyato. In Australia, this species has been referred to as C. zeehaani.

Taxonomic confusion comes from a long history of mistakes in the literature but also from a problem of nomenclature. A recent review by White et al. (2013) included a re-description and the settlement of a neotype of the “larger species” as C. granulosus (Bloch and Schneider 1801). Nomenclature status of this species is pending a paper in preparation that is based on classic taxonomy, review of nomenclature and genetic data, and that will also include a re-description of the species (Guallart et al. 2013, Veríssimo et al. 2014).

At present this assessment is presented under the name C. uyato (Rafinesque 1810) pending this review. It must be noted that this species is assumed not to fit the description made as Squalus uyato by Rafinesque (1810) but its first descriptions of reference are those made as Spinax uyatus by Bonaparte (1834) and Müller and Henle (1839) as C. granulosus.

Rhynchobatus laevis is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. springeri. Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus fedorovi belongs to the spongiceps-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows subequal to, or shorter than the lower furrows.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus herklotsi belongs to the longicephalus-group. This group is characterized by a long, narrow snout (prenarial length >6.4% TL).  A. herklotsi is distinguished from A. longicephalus by the position of the first dorsal fin origin (behind pelvic fin insertion c.f. above pelvic fin base), the spiral valve count (8–12 c.f. 13–17), and a short duodenum as in all other Apristurus species except A. longicephalus (Nakaya 1988, Nakaya 1991, Nakaya and Sato 1999).
Apristurus internatus has been considered a possible junior synonym of Apristurus gibbosus (Nakaya et al. 2008) but is considered valid here.

The genus Apristurus contains at least 39 described species and a number of potentially undescribed ones (Weigmann 2017). Morphological conservatism and, until recently, a lack of objectively defined characters makes this one of the most taxonomically confused shark genera (Compagno 1984, Nakaya and Sato 1999).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus investigatoris belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% TL); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Apristurus atlanticus was previously distinguished from A. laurussonii (Nakaya and Sato 1998), however Iglésias and Nakaya (2004) could not find any significant differences between the holotype of A. atlanticus and A. laurussonii, and therefore consider A. atlanticus to be a junior synonym of A. laurussonii.

Research is required to clarify the taxonomic status of nominal records of A. laurussonii from the US east coast, Gulf of Mexico, and Caribbean (Nakaya and Sato 1998, Kiraly et al. 2003). These records are not considered here to represent A. laurussonii, and as such these regions are not included in this assessment.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus macrorhynchus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows. This species is a local synonym of Broadmouth Catshark (Apristurus macrostomus) in Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013a, Nakaya and Kawauchi 2013).

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species) and spongiceps-group (10 species). A. macrostomus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% TL); 13 to 22 valves in the spiral intestine; upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows; a discontinuous supraorbital sensory canal.

Apristurus micropterygeus is unique among the species of Apristurus in having a narrow and sharply pointed first dorsal fin. However, Nakaya and Sato (2000) recommended that the status of the species be reviewed once additional specimens are available, citing the possibility that the dorsal fin of the holotype may have been malformed.

Nominal records of this species from the Eastern Atlantic are possibly A. manis or another species of Apristurus (Ebert and Stehmann 2013). This species is potentially confused with A. laurussoni of which there are only two confirmed records west of Iceland — one from “Davis Strait” on the Canadian side and the other in the Denmark Strait between Iceland and Greenland (Møller et al. 2010).
Weigmann et al. (2020) revised the genus Pliotrema, describing two new species as distinct from P. warreni: P. annae and P. kajae.

A second species of pocket shark, Mollisquama mississippiensis Grace, Doosey, Denton, Naylor, Bart & Maisey, 2019, was recently described from the Gulf of Mexico in the Western Central Atlantic (Grace et al. 2015, Grace et al. 2019). Mollisquama parini Dolganov, 1984 remains known from only the holotype (Dolganov 1984).
No taxonomic notes.

Note that the type locality reported in Compagno (1984) (Stanley, Falkland Islands) is in error and is correctly Challenger Station 311 (52°45.5'S, 73°46'W), which is in the northwestern Strait of Magellan in the Southeast Pacific (coordinates reported by L.J.V. Compagno in a draft manuscript (unpublished), calculated from Günther's station list in the Challenger Reports; Günther 1887).

Compagno (2001) notes that N. Chirichigno (1980, pers. comm. to Compagno 1984) suggested that there may be two species under Heterodontus quoyi, with some differences between the true H. quoyi from the Galápagos Islands and the Peruvian form. Taylor (1972) examined material from both localities and concluded them to be one species. Compagno (2001) follows Taylor (1972).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

In Chile, a second rhinobatid species is known from just a dried head: Tarsistes philippi Jordan, 1918. The taxonomic situation of this species is not clear.
this species recently moved from Anacanthobatis to Indobatis (Weigmann et al. 2014).

Specimens from off Somalia formerly identified as this species are in fact of the newly described Vivaldi's Catshark (Bythaelurus vivaldii) (Weigmann and Kaschner 2017). A specimen from off northern Tanzania formerly identified as this species is in fact of the newly described Narrowhead Catshark (Bythaelurus tenuicephalus) (Kaschner et al. 2015).
Dipturus campbelli has previously been incorrectly synonymized with D. pullopunctata (Smith, 1964) by Hulley (1988), but this species is distinct (Compagno et al. 1989, Last et al. 2016).
Formerly known as Rajella leopardus but amended to R. leoparda in accordance with the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (Weigmann et al. 2014).

The holotype and only known specimen of Urobatis marmoratus is missing and the species is unrecognizable from the drawing in the original description (which is from 1892). The species was not treated in Last et al. (2016) but is considered valid by Fricke (2020). Additional specimens are required to confirm its validity.

A species of Amblyraja has been taken around South Georgia Island which appears not to be A. georgiana, but may be either A. frerichsi or A. robertsi (Mike Endicott via M. Stehmann pers. comm. 2004). The occurrence of this species in the Falklands Islands (Malvinas) is uncertain. Since the inception of the longline fishery around the islands in 1994, this species has been captured in the Falklands as the primary skate by-catch, and recorded as A. cf. georgiana (J. Pompert unpubl. data 2020).
A careful examination of North Atlantic vs. southern African forms is needed.

When first redescribed, Urolophus armatus was considered to possibly represent a new genus (Séret and Last 2003). A new genus, Spinilophus, has since been erected for this species as it was unique among the Urolophus in having dorsal denticles and thorns with all other Urolophus devoid of squamation (Yearsley and Last 2016).

Genetic differences have been detected between Taiwanese and Japanese specimens of Urolophus aurantiacus but there are no major morphological or meristic differences and further work is needed to determine if this is a consistent difference (Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).

Urobatis concentricus, U. halleri, and U. maculatus have sometimes been considered colour variants of a single species, but molecular studies have shown that these are distinct species (Last et al. 2016).
This species was previously considered to be conspecific with Aetobatus narutobiei, but the species have since been shown to differ genetically and morphologically (White and Moore 2013).
This species is considered distinct from Aetomylaeus milvus (Last et al. 2016).
Myliobatis chilensis is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. peruvianus by colour and rostral fin form.
Myliobatis peruanus was a misspelling of this species. This species is easily differentiated from the sympatric M. chilensis by colour and rostral fin form.
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into the synonymy of Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908. This species is often confused with Common Eagle Ray (Myliobatus aquila).

This species is often confused with the sympatric Persian Gulf Torpedo (Torpedo sinuspercisi), though it can be distinguished by a less reticulate dorsal pattern (Last et al. 2016). There is some taxonomic uncertainty with both species possibly part of a species complex (Last et al. 2016).

The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and based solely on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of a larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).

Last et al. (2016a) revised the family Dasyatidae, erecting the genus Telatrygon. Telatrygon acutirostra resembles other species of Telatrygon in disc shape and was previously confused with T. zugei but is distinguishable by a longer snout and tail, smaller eyes, and less well developed dorsal tail fold (Last et al. 2016a). Phylogenetic and whole genome analyses indicate that T. acutirostra does not cluster with other species of Telatrygon, hence its placement in the group is provisional pending more detailed anatomical studies (Last et al. 2016a).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. This species is commonly misidentified as A. blochii.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status. This species is commonly misidentified as A. annulatus.

Rhynchobatus springeri is part of the Indo-West Pacific Rhynchobatus djiddensis species-complex. The name R. djiddensis has previously been used widely, leading to poorly-defined taxonomy and distributions for members of the complex (in particular, R. australiae, R. djiddensis, and R. laevis). Further investigation into the taxonomy of 'whitespotted wedgefish' is required, and additional species are likely to be described in the future. 

Rhynchobatus yentinensis Wang, 1933 (described from China) might be applicable to this species or may be a synonym of R. laevis.
Finucci et al. (2018) redescribed Chimaera ogilbyi, merging Hydrolagus lemures as a synonym.

This species is part of a complex of giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus, which includes H. affinis and all 'trolli-like' species from Australia and New Zealand, South Africa, the southern Atlantic, and the California coast including the Davidson and San Juan Seamounts in the Eastern Pacific. The giant black Hydrolagus from the Atlantic is likely Hydrolagus affinis; however, the giant black or purple-black species of Hydrolagus from the Pacific may represent at least two separate species, one of which is H. purpurescens (Gilbert, 1905). Hydrolagus eidolon (Jordan & Hubbs, 1925) described from Sagami Bay, Japan, is here considered a synonym of H. purpurescens.

This species belongs to the long-snout group of Centrophorus which includes C. harrissoni, C. isodon, C. seychellorum, and C. westraliensis. The long-snout species group requires further taxonomic attention (White et al. 2017).
Yano et al. (2004) confirm that sleeper sharks found in the South Atlantic Ocean and Southern Ocean are a separate species, Somniosus antarcticus Whitley, 1939.

Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) synonymized Chiloscyllium caerulopunctatum with C. plagiosum, an action tentatively (and reluctantly) followed by Compagno (2001). The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).
Holohalaelurus melanostigma was synonymized with H. punctatus and H. regani until a revision of this genus identified this species as valid (Human 2006).
The West African Catshark has been previously confused with the Nursehound (Scyliorhinus stellaris), which has a more northern distribution.
Heterodontus mexicanus co-occurs with H. francisci in the Gulf of California and these species may be confused in the field. It may be confused with H. quoyi in the southern part of its range.
In geographic regions other than North America sharks referred to as this species are Etmopterus baxteri or Etmopterus unicolor (Compagno and Niem 1998).
The paratype of Bathyraja aguja designated by Kendall and Radcliffe (1912) was found to be distinct and was later described as Bathyraja peruana McEachran & Miyake, 1984.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, but Rhinoraja is now accepted as Bathyraja (Last et al. 2016, Ebert 2016).

While there has been some previous discussion over the validity of Hydrolagus pallidus, recent research confirms that H. pallidus is genetically distinct from H. affinis (Violi et al. 2018). Some genetic evidence suggests H. lusitanicus is synonymous with H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).
Some similarity in external morphology may occur with congeneric Richardson's ray Bathyraja richardsoni, with which the distribution and bathymetric ranges overlap.
Appearance is very similar to Hydrolagus pallidus; recent research confirms that H. affinis is genetically distinctive from H. pallidus (Violi et al. 2018).

The Oxynotus recorded as O. centrina from Angola, Namibia, and South Africa may not be that species but an undescribed one, differing from O. centrina in having a much shorter interdorsal space. If this is correct, the records of O. centrina from tropical West Africa need to be reexamined, but until the problem is resolved the southern and southwestern African Oxynotus is retained in O. centrina (Bass et al. 1976).

Previously this species was synonymized with Galeus melastomus, but it is now considered a valid species supported by both morphometric external field marks and genetic evidence (Muñoz-Chapuli and Perez-Ortega 1985, Rey et al. 2005, 2006, 2010; Castilho et al. 2007).
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.
This species is sometimes called the Spotted Electric Ray, which has resulted in confusion between this species and the Blackspotted Torpedo Ray (Torpedo foscomaculata) (Last et al. 2016).
Moved from Zameus Jordan & Fowler 1903 into Scymnodon Barboza du Bocage & de Brito Capello 1864 by White et al. (2015).
The quality of taxonomic identification of some skate species may be an issue particularly with historic data, however, Bathyraja spinicauda is a relatively easy species to identify.

Nakaya and Sato (1999) defined three species groups within Apristurus: the longicephalus-group (two species), brunneus-group (20 species), and spongiceps-group (10 species). Apristurus japonicus belongs to the brunneus-group, characterized by: a short, wide snout (prenarial length < 6% total length) and upper labial furrows obviously longer than the lower furrows.

There are only two possible specimens from Grand Banks, that have been taken to represent the Western Atlantic. These are likely to be confused with Rajella bathyphila in Canada as older specimens captured there tended to be named Rajella lintea (D. Kulka pers. comm. (20/06/2019).
Anacanthobatis donghaiensis and Anacanthobatis nanhaiensis are now considered junior synonyms of Sinobatis borneensis (Last et al. 2016a, Weigmann 2016).
This species is frequently confused with the Bigtail Skate (Dipturus macrocaudus), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).
White (2014) placed the genus Pteromylaeus Garman, 1913 into synonymy with Aetomylaeus Garman, 1908.
This is the revised taxonomic concept for Scyliorhinus canicula, which now excludes Scyliorhinus duhamelii (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).
This species has been confused with the Polkadot Skate (Dipturus chinensis) in recent literature (Last et al. 2016a).
Changes to the systematics of Rhinobatos elevated the subgenus Glaucostegus to full generic status and placed this genus into a family of its own: Glaucostegidae (Compagno 2005, Last et al. 2016a).

Morphologically similar to some members of the ‘megalops-cubensis group’ but distinguished from those species by the presence of a dark caudal bar. Differs from all other Squalus species in having an unusually low number of precaudal vertebrae (White et al. 2007).
Often confused with Breviraja spinosa.
This species has been confused with Breviraja spinosa in the past.

Sympatric to the Winter Skate (Leucoraja ocellata), immature Little Skates are often confused with immature Winter Skates (especially females). However, the probability of misidentification decreases with skate size as they mature. Skates originally identified as little skate in the Gulf of St. Lawrence were later confirmed as winter skate.

The genus has changed from Raja to Leucoraja (McEachran and Dunn 1998). This assessment assumes a single species. However, populations north of Cape Hatteras have been considered as the subspecies L. garmani virginica while those between the Cape and the Dry Tortugas have been considered as L. g. garmani, but they may represent two distinct species (McEachran 1977, McEachran 2002).
A third nominal species of Narcine from the eastern Pacific, N. schmidti Hildebrand, 1948 is thought to be a junior synonym of N. vermiculata (Carvalho 1999).

Bathyraja matsubarai was first described by Ishiyama (1952), but there has been some level of uncertainty around relationships with other described species. Bathyraja caeluronigricans and B. notoroensis are recognized as junior synonyms of B. matsubarai (Ishihara 1990). Last et al. (2016) note that B. notoroensis is most likely a synonym of B. matsubarai, which was confirmed by Hajime Ishihara (pers. comm., 27/08/2019).

Bathyraja lindbergi Ishiyama & Ishihara, 1977 is also considered by some authors (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999) as a junior synonym of B. matsubarai but that is not followed here and is considered a valid species (Last et al. 2016).
Izu Catshark (Scyliorhinus tokubee) is now a junior synonym of Scyliorhinus torazame (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).

Squalus brevirostris from the northwest Pacific has previously been considered a synonym of S. megalops. A revision of Indo-Pacific Squalus species and molecular data revealed that this species is clearly separable from the true S. megalops from Australia (Last et al. 2007, Weigmann 2016). Misidentifications of the Squalus species in the Northwest Pacific is an issue and may affect the quality of data available for this species.

The description of this species (Dolganov 1983) was based on capture of single specimen caught off Japan. Only several additional specimens have been caught in the Sea of Okhotsk since then (Dudnik and Dolganov 1992) but only few additional taxonomic notes are available (Dolganov and Tuponogov 1999).

authority: Castro-Aguirre, Antuna-Mendiola, González-Acosta & de la Cruz-Agüero, 2005

taxonomicNotes: The abundance and geographic range of this species may have been previously overestimated because of confusion between two species (D. tortonesei and D. pastinaca). It is likely that a distinct Dasyatis species lives in the Mediterranean Sea, but with nomenclature issues that are under investigation (Serena 2005, Last et al. 2016).
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000).
This species is possibly sometimes confused with the smaller Smallspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula).
The distribution of the two other Mustelus species (M. asterias and M. mustelus) overlap with this species and misidentification is probably common.

A species of Amblyraja, previously identified as A. cf. georgiana, occurs around the Falkland Islands (Malvinas) and appears to be most closely related to A. frerichsi. It does however, differ from A. frerichsi in a number of characteristics and may be identical to an undescribed Amblyraja from South Georgia (as specified in Endicott et al. 2002) (J. Pompert pers. comm. 2019). Amblyraja georgiana from the Ross Sea appears to have low-level genetic differentiation from South Atlantic A. georgiana, and further work is required to determine whether the Ross Sea A. georgiana is distinct (M. Francis pers. comm. 2019). Taxonomic resolution of this issue is ongoing. Endicott et al. (2002) found A. georgiana to have a restricted depth range around South Georgia, with an unknown rajid species comprising the rest of the deep water captures. Although A. georgiana is reported to have been regularly caught around Antarctica in deep water, findings by Endicott et al. (2002) suggest that complications and difficulties in identification of Antarctic rajids may lead to misidentification.

In the northwest Atlantic, this species is easily confused with Arctic skate (Amblyraja hyperborea)  (Bigelow and Shroeder 1953). There is clear geographic separation of both species and tooth count distributions are almost completely separated, but all other meristics are not significantly different (D.W. Kulka unpubl. data 2019). Further, Jensen's Skate is genetically indistinguishable from Arctic Skate (Amblyraja hyperborea) using COI barcoding. In-turn the sequence divergence between both these species and Badia’s Skate (A. badia) is minimal (0.2 to 0.3%). This could result from (1) hybridization, (2) they are all the same species, or (3) “recent divergence and insufficient time for reciprocal monophyly to have occurred” and distinguishing among these hypotheses would require evaluation with other molecular markers (Coulson et al. 2011).

This species has been relocated from the genus Okamejei to Orbiraja (Last et al. 2016). The taxonomic status of this species is uncertain. Orbiraja philipi has been considered a possible synonym of Orbiraja powelli Alcock 1898 by Séret (1989) and further specimens are needed to determine its validity (Last et al. 2016).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was recently revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000), which is generally accepted. This species was previously known as Galeus arae antillensis (in part).

This species is morphologically varied and sometimes difficult to distinguish from other members of the G. arae complex. It is however, separated from its congeners by the combination of the presence of a ventral precaudal crest of enlarged denticles, colour pattern and vertebral counts (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998). It occurs sympatrically with G. antillensis.
Poroderma marleyi was previously considered separate from P. pantherinum, however, it has been shown that P. marleyi represents an extreme colour pattern of P. pantherinum (Human 2006).
Gymnura tentaculata identified from Papua New Guinea (Kailola 1987) are a misidentification of G. australis, as G. tentaculata appears to be restricted to the Northern Indian Ocean.
Previously included a junior synonym, the Maculate Panray (Zanobatus maculatus), which is now a separate species (Last et al. 2016).

Last et al. (2016a) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. Records of Dasyatis (=Fontitrygon) margaritella have included misidentified specimens of the larger sympatric species, F. margarita.
A comparison of Southeastern to North Atlantic specimens should be carried out to determine if both populations are the same species.
This species is very similar to Narcine maculata but can be distinguished by dorsal coloration and the nostril and mouth proportions (Last et al. 2016)
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.

Holohalaelurus grennian was originally included within H. melanostigma (Norman, 1939), was then synonymized with H. punctatus (Bass et al. 1975), and in recent years was included in the East African Holohalaelurus species-complex (Compagno 1988). However, H. grennian is clearly distinct from all other Holohalaelurus taxa (Human 2006).
Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including pastinacoides).
McEachran and Dunne (1998) moved this species from genus Raja to Amblyraja.

Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only Urogymnus asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) moved five more medium to large species to Urogymmus, including lobistomus. This species is probably misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) uarnacoides and Himantura (=Pateobatis) hortlei (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007).
Last et al. (2016a) assigned this species to the recently described genus Orbiraja.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.
Sympatric with the Chinese Numbfish (Narcine lingula) and distinguished by the oronasal region morphology (Last et al. 2016).

It is unclear whether this, or a similar, species occurs along the east and west African coasts and Mediterranean Sea. A systematic review of this species is needed in these areas. This species is sometimes confused with Duckbill Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus bovinus).

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from Southeast Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea. This species is potentially endemic to the Arabian Sea, however, further taxonomic work is required in the Bay of Bengal to determine if this species occurs there or if recorded specimens refer to L. tephrodes.

Historically there has been confusion between Holohalaelurus regani and other members of the genus. Holohalaelurus favus was previously considered to be a subspecies of H. regani, however, it is distinct from H. regani (Human 2006).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Iwatsuki et al. (2011) revised the genus Platyrhina, describing two new species as distinct from Platyrhina sinensis.
Last et al. (2016a) described the genus Pateobatis, consisting of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including hortlei).

Raja miraletus was considered wide-ranging in the Eastern Atlantic, but this is a species-complex with R. miraletus occurring in the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean, R. parva occurring off West Africa, and R. ocellifera off South Africa (Last and Séret 2016).
Some published records of this species may be a result of misidentification of the Roughbelly Skate (Dipturus springeri), which is similar in appearance.
No taxonomic notes.
Several published works have suggested that Bathyraja smirnovi may be a synonym of B. parmifera. However, B. smirnovi is widely recognised as a valid species (see Dyldin and Orlov 2018).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species is similar to  the Leopard Whipray (H. leoparda) (Last et al. 2016). The Honeycomb Whipray juveniles of 50 cm disc width (DW) have a well-developed main denticle band with inconspicuous primary denticles while the adults have a strong pattern of large ocelli and reticulations.

Sympatric to the Little Skate, immature specimens of the two species are often confused, especially females. However, chance of misidentification decreases as they mature. Disk is rounded, with many small dark spots on upper surface. Usually 1-4 ocelli are found on the upper surface on each side of disk, each with a dark brownish center and pale edge. Young have long middorsal row of large spines on disk and tail. Upper jaw has 72 rows of teeth. Lower surface is usually white but marked with irregular pale brownish blotches (although this colouration is found in several other species within range).

This species has been previously confused with the Marbled Stingray Dasyatis marmorata and the Common Stingray D. pastinaca, neither of which overlap with the range of the Blue Stingray (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to be conspecific with the Speckled Catshark (H. boesemani) but taxonomy has been resolved. Confusion with the Blackspotted Catshark (H. buergeri) possible and referred to in White et al. (2006) as the Indonesian Spotted Catshark (H. cf. buergeri).

Okamejei kenojei has various morphotypes, which previously lead to some taxonomic confusion. Ishihara (1987, 1990) synonymised Raja atriventralis, R. fusca, R. japonica, R. katsukii, R. kenojei, R. porosa, and R. tobae with (Ishihara et al. 2002).

Previously this species was referred to as a subpopulation of Holohalaelurus regani (occurring off KwaZulu-Natal and southern Mozambique). A revision of the genus Holohalaelurus has shown that this species is in fact distinct from H. regani (Human 2006). Specimens of H. favus were first referred to and illustrated by Bass et al. (1975).

Previously considered a "Natal" form of Haploblepharus edwardsii (Schinz, 1822) by Bass et al. (1975) and subsequent authors, H. kistnasamyi has a colour pattern that superficially resembles, although is distinct from, that of H. edwardsii, and also differs in morphological features (Human and Compagno 2006). DNA Barcoding confirms that H. kistnasamyi is distinct from H. edwardsii and other Haploblepharus species (K. Geldhill, unpubl. data, 2018).
Ishihara et al. (2012) established the new genus Beringraja for the two species B. binoculata  (previously Raja binoculata Girard, 1855) and B. pulchra (previously Raja pulchra Liu 1932).

Tentatively placed in the genus Sinobatis Hulley 1973 by White and Last (2013). According to White and Last (2013), this species should be considered as questionably valid pending a thorough review of the western North Pacific anacanthobatids.
The revision of the genus Holohalaelurus showed that H. polystigma is a junior synonym of H. punctatus (Human 2006).

This species was previously provisionally considered to occur in Australia but now the Australian and other Indo-Pacific long-tailed torpedo rays are considered to be variants of other species (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016). Around Taiwan, this species has been confused with Tetronarce formosa (Ebert et al. 2013).

The Triangular Legskate (Cruriraja parcomaculata) was described by von Bonde and Swart (1923) from off KwaZulu-Natal. Smith (1964) later described a small legskate from off Durban as C. triangularis. However, examination of the type specimens of both C. parcomaculata and C. triangularis confirmed that both species were one in the same. A common legskate from off the south and west coasts of South Africa and Namibia commonly referred to as C. parcomaculata was determined not to be that species, but an undescribed legskate. Aschliman et al. (2010) after a reviewing these species described a new species C. hulleyi while synonymizing C. triangularis as a junior synonym of C. parcomaculata. Therefore, information on the life history and distribution of C. triangularis prior to 2010 should now be referred to as C. parcomaculata, and life history and distribution previously referred to for west coast C. parcomaculata is referable to as C. hulleyi. See Aschliman et al. (2010) for further explanation of this issue.
No taxonomic notes.

Himantura uarnak was recently split from other Himantura species (Last et al. 2016a). The new distribution no longer includes Australia and Papua New Guinea (Last et al. 2016b). There is some continued taxonomic uncertainty with the Himantura genus and this assessment should be updated if the current distribution changes.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, elevating the former subgenus Acroteriobatus to generic status.

Dolganov and Tuponogov (1999) suggest that B. trachouros may be synonymous with B. violacea (Ishihara pers. obs.), however, B. trachouros is treated as a valid species here (clasper structure is distinct) and was recognized as valid by Compagno (2005).
Often confused with Breviraja claramaculata.

The specimen from off Tanzania identified as Cruriraja andamanica by McEachran and Fechhelm (1982) was found to be well-separated (i.e. the ordination of principle components with respect to its morphometric vectors fell outside the 90% confidence ellipse area) from the holotype and other specimens (Vinu et al. 2017). These authors conclude that this Tanzanian specimen is questionable and should be thoroughly re-evaluated to determine whether it might represent a separate species that has yet to be described.

Himantura kittipongi, H. oxyrhynchus, and H. signifer were placed within the newly described genus Fluvitrygon (Last et al. 2016a). This species is most similar to H. signifer, from which it differs in having thorny denticles on the tail and no pale edge to the disc (Last et al. 2016b).

Cephaloscyllium umbratile was recognized as a distinct species by Nakaya (1975). Later, Springer (1979) treated C. umbratile as a junior synonym of C. isabellum. However, recent workers such as Compagno et al. (2005) and Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) treat C. umbratile as a distinct species and Nakaya et al. (2013) also recognized it as a valid species. The sympatric C. formosanum was considered a junior synonym of C. umbratile by Schaaf-da Silva & Ebert (2008) but resurrected as a valid species by Nakaya et al. (2013).
This species has previously been confused with Okamejei kenojei (Ishihara et al. 2009).

This is a member of the Galeus arae complex of the Western Atlantic. The taxonomy of this complex was revised with former subspecies now listed as full species (Konstantinou and Cozzi 1998, Konstantinou et al. 2000). This species was previously known as Galeus arae antillensis (in part) and was noted as the island form of Galeus arae (Springer 1979).
This species may get confused with Atelomycterus marmoratus which is more widespread in the region and co-occurs off the island of Bali (White et al. 2005).
This species is frequently confused with the Giant Skate (Dipturus gigas), particularly at the juvenile stage (Ebert et al. 2013).

Genetic studies show that B. eatonii in the southern Atlantic is distinct from populations in the Ross Sea (Pacific) and Indian Ocean (Smith and McVeagh 2004, M. Francis pers. comm. 2007). Therefore this Red List assessment is restricted to B. eatonii in the Atlantic Ocean, and data from other areas excluded, as these are considered to refer to, as yet, unidentified but similar species. Hulley’s (1988) suggestion that B. eatonii may be synonymous with B. smithii, (found off South Africa) is probably not correct (Stehmann and Bürkel 1990).
The genus Hemitrygon formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis; it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016a) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.
Squalus acutipinnis is a recently resurrected member of the megalops-cubensis group of Squalus species (Viana and Carvalho 2016). It was previously referred to locally as Squalus megalops.

Dasyatis marmorata is a species occurring off western Africa. This species has often been confused with Dasyatis chrysonota, which is a South African species. However, molecular data supports the non-conspecificity of these two species (Last et al. 2016a).
Squalus bassi has previously been referred to locally as Squalus mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2017).

Dipturus wuhanlingi was described in 2008 (Jeong and Nakabo 2008). Among the Dipturus species distributed in the western North Pacific (i.e., Dipturus gigas, D. kwangtungensis, D. macrocauda, D. tengu, and D. wuhanlingi) this species has the unique character of a continuous row of mid-dorsal thorns from nape to the tail distinguishing it from other regional Dipturus spp. The validity of this species is not doubtful.
Squalus mahia is a recently described Squalus of the megalops-cubensis group (Viana et al. 2018).
Squalus margaretsmithae is a recently described Squalus of the megalops-cubensis group (Viana et al. 2018).

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.
 
In previous IUCN Red List publications Gymnura marmorata included G. crebripunctata as a synonym. Therefore assessments of G. marmorata from 2012 onwards are not directly comparable with previous assessments under that name.

There has been a great deal of historic uncertainty regarding the taxonomic status of Eastern Pacific gymnurids, with some authors considering Gymnura crebripunctata to be a junior synonym of G. marmorata. However, Smith et al. (2009) confirmed the validity of G. crebripunctata as a distinct species using both morphometric and molecular techniques.

Recently, molecular data confirmed that the single, widespread Indo–Pacific species, Pastinachus sephen consists of two species, the widespread P. ater and a more restricted P. sephen (Last et al. 2016a).

While there are reported subpopulations of Squalus acanthias (Linnaeus, 1758) elsewhere in the world, the North Pacific subpopulation is now considered a separate species, Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) (see Ebert et al. 2010). Further taxonomic studies on this genus are required, including in relation to Mediterranean and Black Sea subpopulations. In Europe, three subpopulations are inferred to occur.

Raja miraletus was considered wide-ranging in the Eastern Atlantic, but is a species-complex with R. miraletus occurring in the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea, R. parva occurring off West Africa, and R. ocellifera off South Africa (Last and Séret 2016).

Dingerkus and DeFino (1983) synonymized Chiloscyllium caerulopunctatum with C. plagiosum, an action tentatively (and reluctantly) followed by Compagno (2001). The species name is not addressed in Ebert et al. (2013), however, C. caerulopunctatum is considered to be distinct from C. plagiosum and thus a valid species (W. White pers. comm. cited in Weigmann 2016).
Squalus albicaudus is a member of the Squalus megalops species-complex. The taxonomic description includes specimens that were formerly identified as S. megalops and S. cubensis (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus bahiensis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. The taxonomic description includes mostly specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei and S. mitsukurii, and fewer specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. fernandinus.
Squalus lobularis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus quasimodo is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei, S. fernandinus, S. lebruni, and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

authority: Díaz de Astarloa, Mabragaña, Hanner & Figueroa, 2008
taxonomicNotes: Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus, thereby relegating this species to the genus Dipturus.

Vaz and Carvalho (2018) carried out morphological analysis of South- and Northwestern Atlantic specimens of Squatina revealing this previously undescribed species of angel shark occurring on the continental slope of Brazil between latitudes 11° and 22°S.
Séret and Naylor (2016) described Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis (and Rhynchorhina as a new genus) from limited specimens collected off Mauritania (Eastern Central Atlantic).

The new taxonomic concept for Squatina guggenheim includes S. punctata as a junior synonym.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

This species is often misidentified with the Taiwan Angelshark (Squatina formosa). Diagnostic features for this species include pelvic fin tips which extend to origin of the first dorsal fin and angular pelvic, dorsal, and caudal fins (Walsh et al. 2011).

This species is often misidentified with other regional Squatinids. Diagnostic features for Squatina japonica include pelvic fin tips which do not reach the first dorsal origin and spines along the midback line (Walsh et al. 2011).
Specimens from various parts of the species' patchy range need to be critically examined to understand if these represent the same species.

This species was described with no type specimen and locality, but it has been presumed to be from the Arabian Gulf (Wallace 1967, Compagno 1986, Carvalho et al. 2002). It is considered to be one of the most widely distributed electric rays of the Western Indian Ocean (Carvalho et al. 2002, Last et al. 2016). However, the status of this species is uncertain as it is possibly a species-complex (Last et al. 2016). It is highly variable and confused with the Panther Torpedo (Torpedo panthera) (Last et al. 2016). The present account is therefore provisional, and in the event that species within the complex are better delineated, reassessment will be required (this may result in the status of electric rays being revised upwards, on the basis of small populations with localized distributions).

Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from Carcharhinus porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

authority: Del Moral-Flores, Ramíz-Antonio, Angulo & Pérez-Ponce de León, 2015
taxonomicNotes: Morales-Flores et al. (2015) described Ginglymostoma unami as distinct from Ginglymostoma cirratum. Ginglymostoma unami is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and G. cirratum to the Atlantic.

The Shorttail Yellownose Skate (Dipturus brevicaudatus) was split out from the former species concept of Zearaja chilensis (Gabbanelli et al. 2018). Concha et al. (2019) re-described Zearaja chilensis as Dipturus chilensis and subsumed the genus Zearaja Whitley 1939 as a junior synonym of Dipturus Rafinesque 1810.
The Clown Wedgefish is a recently described small species of wedgefish (Last et al. 2016). It is a distinct species which is not likely to be confused with other Rhynchobatus species.

The taxonomic concept for Bigeye Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus nakamurai) has been revised and the Atlantic Sixgill Shark (Hexanchus vitulus) has now been resurrected to a separate species that occurs in the Western Central Atlantic Ocean (Daly-Engel et al. 2019).

authority: Grace, Doosey, Denton, Naylor, Bart & Maisey, 2019
taxonomicNotes: This species is known only from the holotype collected in 2010. It is distinct from Mollisquama parini Dolganov, 1984, the only other member of the genus (Grace et al. 2015, Grace et al. 2019).

The species may be misidentified with other members of the Etmoperus lucifer clade (Ebert et al. 2017).
The Longfin Gulper Shark is recently described (White et al. 2017). An extremely long-based first dorsal fin is distinctive and distinguishes it from other Centrophorus species.

The genus Scoliodon, represented by S. laticaudus, was previously considered monotypic but now consists of three species with S. macrorhynchus resurrected from the junior synonym of S. laticaudus (White et al. 2010).

This species has been confused with the Kwangtung Skate (Dipturus kwangtunensis) that occurs further south; the Polkadot Skate has a shorter snout and more symmetrical pattern on blotches on the dorsal surface (Last et al. 2016).

The taxonomy of Lamiopsis has recently been resolved with White et al. (2010) resurrecting and redescribing Lamiopsis tephrodes from South-east Asia, and Akhilesh et al. (2016) redescribing Lamiopsis temminckii from the Arabian Sea.

taxonomicNotes: This cryptic species is most closely related to the Scalloped Hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini), and is morphologically distinguishable by the number of precaudal vertebrae (Quattro et al. 2013).
The Bay of Bengal population may represent a separate dwarf Iago omanensis-like species (Fernando et al. 2019, Psomadakis et al. 2019).
Previously confused with the Whitespotted Whipray (Maculabatis gerrardi) from which it can be distinguished based on colour and morphometrics (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2016).

Last et al. (2016) described the genus Maculabatis, comprised of nine medium to large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including gerrardi). Reports of the species are often confused with the Coach Whipray (Himantura uarnak).

It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. Last et al. (2016) described the genus Pateobatis, comprised of five medium-size to very large, marine whiprays previously placed in Himantura (including bleekeri). Previously on The IUCN Red List bleekeri was treated as a junior synonym of uarnacoides (M. Manjaji pers. obs. 2007). However, Pateobatis bleekeri is considered a valid species by Last et al. Atelomycterus erdmanni is closely related to A. baliensis and A. marmoratus, being sympatric with the latter (Fahmi and White 2015).

Hemitriakis indroyonoi is separable from the other congeners, H. abdita, H. complicofasciata, H. falcata, H. japanica and H. leucoperiptera, by a combination of vertebral counts, morphometric characters, and juvenile colouration (White et al. 2009).

This species has been confused with its congener the Japanese Wobbegong (Orectolobus japonicus). Species referred to as Orectolobus japonicus are likely a complex of Western Indian Ocean species including this species and the complex requires further taxonomic work (Last et al. 2010a, Last et al. 2010b).

The species is distinguished from Philippine Guitarfish (Rhinobatos whitei) and Goldeneye Guitarfish (R. sainsbury) by colour, morphology, and meristic characters (White et al. 2016).

This species has probably been misidentified as Himantura (=Pateobatis) fai in the literature (W. White pers. obs). More specimens of both this species and of H. draco from South Africa need to be examined to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Presently, H. draco is considered a synonym of P. jenkinsii. The South African species had dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc, but this form has also been reported from the Arafura Sea and off Sumatra in Indonesia. It is possible that these may in fact be colour forms of the same species. Examples of specimens with dark spots along the posterior margin of the disc are from the Arafura Sea, Sumatra (Last and Stevens 1994, Fahmi pers. obs. 2007), and from western Sri Lanka (Morón et al. 1998, Manjaji 2004), and the Sulu Sea (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto pers. obs. 2002).
Formerly a monotypic genus (containing only U. asperrimus), Last et al. (2016) added five more species to Urogymmus, including U. granulatus.

Concha et al. (2019) synonymised the genus Zearaja with Dipturus based on morphological and molecular analyses, thus assigning species formerly in the genus Zearaja to Dipturus. The species Dipturus chilensis formerly was considered as occurring in both the Southeast Pacific and the Southwest Atlantic. However, Gabbanelli et al. (2018) resurrected Raja brevicaudata Marini, 1933 from Argentina out of synonymy with D. chilensis and Concha et al. (2019) described Dipturus lamillai Concha, Caira, Ebert & Pompert, 2019 as a distinct species from the Falkland Islands (Malvinas), Southwest Atlantic. Therefore, D. chilensis is restricted to the Southeast Pacific, from central Chile to the Strait of Magellan, and references to D. chilensis in the Southwest Atlantic refer either to D. brevicaudatus or D. lamillai.
The taxonomy of this species remains unresolved and it may prove to be a synonym of the Smallspot Numbfish Narcine maculata (Last et al. 2016).

Previously considered to also occur in the Northwest Pacific, a separate species that is likely endemic to the Northwest Pacific, that is Squalus formosus, has now been split from S. blainville and S. blainville occurs only in the eastern Atlantic, Mediterranean and Black Sea (White and Iglésias 2013). This species has a historically unstable nomenclature that has confused its identification with other Squalus spp. across its range (Veríssimo et al. 2017).
This species has been split from Gymnura micra and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of clasper morphology and disc shape (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).
