This recently described species can be distinguished from the regional congener the Yellowspotted Skate (Leucoraja wallacei) by its elongated snout and a dorsal surface pattern of a single ocelli at the mid-base of each pectoral fin, paired small white spots, and no banding on its tail (Ebert and Leslie 2019).

The newly described species differs from congeneric North Pacific species (S. mitsukurii and S. japonicus) in having fewer vertebrae, larger dorsal fin bases with a shorter interdorsal space, and a more posterior origin of the pelvic fins (Dolganov 2019, Viana and Carvalho 2020).

This recently described species is distinguished by a lack of mid-dorsal thorns, three pairs of white blotches on the dorsal disc surface, and dark bands on the mid-ventral line of the tail (Misawa et al. 2020).

The newly described Hemiscyllium michaeli Allen & Dudgeon, 2010 has been split from H. freycineti. As such, H. freycineti is now considered to be restricted to western New Guinea, whereas H. michaeli occurs in eastern New Guinea (Allen et al. 2016).

Hemiscyllium galei was recently described as a separate species by Allen and Erdmann (2008). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti), which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern, which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates H. galei from other hemiscyllid species including H. freycineti.

Henry’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium henryi) is most similar to the Epaulette Shark (H. ocellatum) which has previously been thought to exist in Papua New Guinea, but likely is not found there. The latter species is most likely restricted to Australian waters (Allen and Erdmann 2008). Colour pattern features and DNA analysis provide the best means of separation between the two species.

Michael’s Epaulette Shark (Hemiscyllium michaeli) has recently been described as a new species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010). It was previously confused with the Indonesian Speckled Carpet Shark (H. freycineti) (Compagno 2002) which is apparently restricted to West Papua Province (far western New Guinea), Indonesia. The two species differ primarily in colour pattern which provides the best means of separating the various members of the genus. Phylogenetic analysis with mitochondrial DNA (ND4) also clearly separates the two species (Allen and Dudgeon 2010).

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted; a revision is underway with the Ph.D. thesis of Jimena San Martin.

This recently described species can be distinguished from its most closely-related regional congener, the Mangrove Whipray (Urogymnus granulatus) by a more angular snout, no white flecks on the dorsal surface, a uniformly white ventral surface with no broad black margin, and a longer tail (Last et al. 2016a).
Easily confused with the Southern Eagle Ray (Myliobatis goodei) (Last et al. 2016).

The Whitespotted Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narinari) (Euphrasen 1790) was originally restricted to the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic (Sales et al. 2019) but the range now also extends to the eastern Atlantic (Fricke et al. 2020).

Torpedo peruana Chirichigno, 1963 is tentatively recognised as a synonym of Tetronarce tremens (de Buen, 1959) (Carvalho et al. 2002). Torpedo microdiscus is also now included as a synonym of T. tremens (Carvalho et al. 2016).
Crassinarke dormitor is now included as a synonym of Narke japonica (Compagno and Heemstra 2007, Carvalho et al. 2016).

The Common Blue Skate (Dipturus batis) and Flapper Skate (Dipturus intermedius) were synonymised in a taxonomic revision of European skates (Rajidae) in the 1920s (Clark 1926), before being recognised again as separate species in 2010 (Iglésias et al. 2010). Consequently, information for both species were reported as ‘Dipturus batis’ (the 'common skate complex') for much of the 20th and early 21st centuries.
Records of this species off Argentina refer to Mustelus schmitti.

Cotton unpubl. data 2020). Prior western Atlantic records of Squalus blainville may refer to this species (Kiraly et al. 2003, Pfleger et al. 2018), however eastern records of S. blainville represent a different species (Pfleger et al. 2018). Old records of S. acanthias in the Gulf of Mexico (and its junior synonyms S. fernandinus and S. barbouri) likely refer to this species (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

This species has been split from Gymnura micrura and is morphologically similar but can be distinguished on the basis of internal diagnostic characters such as the contour of the hyomandibula (Yokota and de Carvalho 2017).

Reports of G. obtusus from South Africa are considered invalid and based on other species (Compagno and Last 1999).

This newly-described species can be distinguished from the sympatric Sculpted Lanternshark (Etmopterus sculptus) by an indistinct colour gradation between the flank and abdomen compared to a sharp demarcation, a V-shaped arrangement of ampullae on the ventral snout compared to a U-shaped arrangement, and dorsal fins densely covered with dermal denticles compared to sparse or mostly bare dorsal fins (Ebert et al. 2021a).

This newly-described species can be distinguished from its most closely related congener, the Arabian Smoothhound (M. mosis), by its subdivided palatoquadrate compared to an undivided palatoquadrate and shorter labial furrows that are also shorter than the lower labial furrows (White et al. 2021).
This newly-described species is the only Notoraja species known from the western Indian Ocean and is an intense, dark blue colour (Weigmann et al. 2021).

For more than 100 years, Raja arctowskii (Dollo, 1904) was known only from three empty egg capsules; the species remained undescribed due to the lack of specimens that could be assigned to those capsules. In 2021, after trawled egg capsules and an egg capsule containing a near-term embryo became available, a full description of this species was published by Stehmann et al. (2021), placing the species in the genus Bathyraja.

This newly-described species is distinguished from its congeners by the combination of a massive head with short snout, stocky and relatively long trunk, short tail, and long pelvic fin anterior margin (Iglésias et al. 2022).

It is difficult to distinguish some members of the genus based solely on morphology, thus the true distribution and overlap of species is not currently known. Previously misidentified as Neotrygon kuhlii, Last et al. (2016a) resurrected Neotrygon varidens as the valid name for this ray. A study using allozymes as a genetic marker (Eitner 1995) indicated that an unrecognized fourth species of Alopias may exist, however this claim was based on data from a single shark specimen likely to have been A. vulpinus. Recent work investigating population structure of all three Alopias species using mitochondrial DNA control region sequences (Trejo 2005) has found no evidence indicating that a fourth species of thresher sharks exists.

Combined morphological and molecular data led Last et al. (2016) and White et al. (2017) to conclude that Mobula eregoodootenkee is a junior synonym of M. kuhlii. However, Hosegood et al. (2019) suggested these were separate species, which was supported by Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020), who also clarified the nomenclature as M. eregoodoo.

Recent revisions of the taxonomy of genus Mobula included the decision to consider the circumglobal Spinetail Devil Ray M. japanica (Müller & Henle, 1841) a junior synonym of the Mediterranean Giant Devil Ray M. mobular (Bonnaterre, 1788), causing M. mobular to become a circumglobal species (Poortvliet et al. 2015, Hosegood et al. 2018, White et al. 2018).

Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. (2020) argued that one of the traits that were used to support the differentiation between the two species, the maximum size of M. mobular purportedly in excess of 5 m disc width (DW), can be explained by past misidentifications of M. birostris, and therefore unsubstantiated. This also supports their recommendation to retain for the species the common name “Spinetail Devil Ray” instead of “Giant Devil Ray”.

The previously monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated in 2009 with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Oceanic Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018)

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Reef Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.

This species was recently described by Habib and Islam (2021). It is similar to, and sympatric with, Glaucostegus granulatus in Bangladesh, but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.

A newly-described species, Glaucostegus younholeei Habib & Islam, 2021, is sympatric with G. granulatus in Bangladesh but the description of the new species does not change the taxonomic concept of G. granulatus.
